Because of this business, this woman and her family were able to build their own home, and get furniture and electric appliances to furnish it.  All of these achievements were thanks to her coffee crops and her good marketing.  She now also has a business selling soft drinks, beer, and necessities out of her house, which is the only one with a phone in the area.  She says that she is happy with her achievements because she earned everything she has with sweat and hard work.

What's more, Fortunata doesn't stay in one place; she sells the fruits that she produces on her agricultural plots in Lima and, to increase her produce supply, she buys more fruit from her neighbors and from the wholesale market.

Because they are eager to move forward, Fortunata and Nila want to see their children become professional people with a good education.  In order to achieve this, they will continue to work and invest in their businesses.  This would be their tenth loan with MFP, which is why they make sure to make their payments on time.  She likes working with her communal bank because of the informal, friendly atmosphere.  Upon receiving the money, she will buy necessities as well as soft drinks and beer, which she will sell in the store she runs out of her home.

loans.use: to buy cases of beer and soft drinks

loans.name: Danston

texts.en:
Danston is 51 years old and has been in farming for 20 years. His farm currently produces maize, milk and vegetables for the local market. He earns additional income from his employment as a machine attendant in a local factory.

Danston has requested a loan of 35,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase poultry birds for a venture into poultry farming. He says he wants to diversify his farming business and hopes he will be able to adequately meet his family's needs from the farming income. He says his top priority is the education of his children, six of whom are still in school. He also aspires to intensify his dairy farming and become a breeder in the future.

Danston says the major challenge in dairy farming is sourcing quality animals since there are no trusted breeders in the area coupled with a lack of government records for breeds, which makes identification of quality breeds a nightmare for farmers.

loans.use: to buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Fifagbe 2 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe FIFAGBE 2 est composé de quatre personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. C'est la quatrième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante  du groupe, du nom de Germaine est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Germaine est âgée de 32 ans et vit au Bénin. Germaine a arrêté l’école au niveau primaire. Germaine ne vit plus avec son mari. Germaine es t mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés et à sa charge. Germaine vit seule avec ses enfants. Germaine assure seule les diverses charges de la maison. Afin de subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Germaine mène comme activité depuis une dizaine d’année, la vente de produits vivriers (maïs etc..) et des charbons de bois dans son quartier. Germaine s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Germaine sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe FIFAGBE 2, un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les trois premiers prêts ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
The Fifagbe 2 group consists of four people who live in the same neighborhood. This is the fourth time that this group is requesting financial aid from ALIDé, in order to elevate the level of their business.

The representative of the group, by the name of Germaine, is the one who has her hand raised in the photo. Germaine is 32 years old and lives in Bénin. Germaine stopped school at the primary level. Germaine does not live with her husband anymore. Germaine is mother to two children who both go to school and are under her care. Germaine lives alone with her children. Germaine takes care of the diverse household responsibilities alone.

In order to meet her needs and those of her children, Germaine has been managing a business selling food products (corn etc.) and charcoal in her neighborhood for about ten years. Germaine gets her supplies in a market of Bénin. 

In order to satisfy her clientèle and to grow her turnover and her income, Germaine is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé, together with the other members of the Fifagbe 2 group. The first three loans were well repaid.

loans.use: to buy food products (corn, etc.) and bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Hourng's Group

texts.en:
Houl is a 33-year-old father of 3 dependent children, 2 of whom are still in school while the third helps with the family's business. He is a farmer who has been farming his own plot of land for five years. He also plants rubber trees to generate extra income. He currently earns around US $8 per day to support his family.

Houl and his group member have just joined VisionFund this loan cycle. As the leader of this group, he will use this loan to buy fertilizer for his rubber plantation. He hopes that he will gain more income from this business and make a better living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for his rubber plantation.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua is a successful second-hand clothing seller in Abura, near Cape Coast. She has been educated through the end of senior high school. She is married to a petty trader and has two children. 

Ekua has been in her business for five years. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband pay their children's school fees. 

Her loan will be used to increase her current stock levels. Ekua hopes to use the new profits from her business to grow her second-hand clothing business and to increase her capital base, as well as to improve the standard of living of her family.

loans.use: to increase her current stock levels of second-hand clothing to sell.

loans.name: Franklin

texts.fr: Franklin est un homme de 33 ans commerçant dans un quartier un quartier de la place où il a ouvert un cybercafé. Son activité fonctionne bien d'où la nécessité de ce crédit pour lui parce qu'il permettra d'augmenter les  machines pour une meilleure satisfaction de sa clientèle. ceci augmentera aussi sa marge bénéficiaire qui sera en partie réinvesti dans son activité pour l'agrandir.
texts.en:
Franklin is a 33-year-old man who is a businessman in a local neighbourhood.  He owns and runs a successful internet café.

Franklin plans to use his loan to buy more machines for his business, which will improve his customer satisfaction and therefore, his profits.  He will reinvest part of his profit into his business in order to expand it further.

loans.use: to increase his stock of computers for his business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To raise their capital in order to meet customers demand.

loans.name: Narmina

texts.en: Narmina is a low-income person, originally from the Shamakhi district of Azerbaijan. She now lives in Baku. She started her clothing business in 1999 with her own money. During 2005-2006 she borrowed two times from the Normicro Baku branch and used the process to expand her business considerably. Now Narmina would like to borrow an additional $1,200 to further develop her business in order to cover her family's expenses.

loans.use: To increase goods variety

loans.name: Julia Nancy

texts.en:
Mrs. Nancy has 30 years' experience with her grocery store business. She first started selling clothing going to different towns each week. After saving a little bit of money and with the help of her husband they were able to open the grocery store. She works every day of the week from 6 a.m. to 11 p.m. Her husband has a small car that she uses to buy new supplies.

Nancy wants to use the loan to invest in her business and buy new products that she hasn’t sold before. She already has some orders from the people in the area where she lives.

Nancy is 49 years old. She is married and has 3 children. Two of them are old enough to help her when needed. Her husband works in a company as a machinery operator. In the afternoons, he goes out in his small car to make some deliveries. Nancy’s wish is to be able to recondition the store and find a better location for it. She hopes to make it bigger and have a bigger inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Nancy tiene una experiencia de 30 años con su negocio de venta de víveres para el hogar. Ella se inicio con la venta de ropa por la que viajaba a los pueblos cada semana. Luego poco a poco fue ahorrando dinero y con la ayuda de su esposo logran poner su tiendita. La trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 6 a.m. hasta las 11 p.m. Su esposo posee un carrito con el cual van a comprar cuando necesitan surtir la tienda.

Nancy desea el crédito para invertir en el negocio y surtirlo con otros productos que no posee. Va ha invertir en artículos varios ya que tiene pedidos del sector donde vive.

Nancy tiene 49 años. Es casada y tres hijos . Dos de ellos ya tiene compromiso y le ayudan en lo que ella necesita. Su esposo también trabaja en una empresa de operador de maquina. Por las tardes luego de su trabaja sale a realizar fletes con su carrito que tiene. El deseo de Nancy es poder acondicionar su tienda y darle una mejor ubicación. Espera a futuro hacerla mas grande y surtirla.

loans.use: Buy more merchandise to have a bigger inventory.

loans.name: Isela Patricia

texts.es:
Isela Patricia is a very hard working woman and has a great desire to better herself. She is married and has a 12 year old daughter and an 8 year old son. Her husband is a factory worker where she lives. However, his salary is very low. In order to help with her home's expenses, Isela took an imitation jewellery course and has been making necklaces, bracelets and earings for five years. Having good quality products has helped her business grow and the number of clients increase continuously.

For her business to continue growing, Isela requires a loan of US $325. She will use this loan to purchase the raw material that she needs. She is committed to repay this loan within six months. Be part of this business' growth and help better this family's life. Thank you very much.

Translated from Spanish by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer.

Isela Patricia es una mujer muy trabajadora y con grandes deseos de superación, ella es casada y tiene una hija de 12 años de edad y un hijo de 8 años. Su esposo es obrero en una fábrica de su localidad, pero el salario que recibe es muy bajo, para ayudar a su esposo en los gastos del hogar Isela tomó un curso de bisutería y desde hace cinco años se dedica a este oficio. Ella confecciona pulseras, collares y aretes de piedras finas y la calidad de los productos que ella elabora la han ayudado a hacer crecer su negocio e incrementar su número de clientes continuamente.

Para poder continuar creciendo e incrementar su producción Isela requiere de un préstamo de $ 325 dólares que empleará en la compra de los insumos que necesita, ella se compromete a devolver esta cantidad en 6 meses. Se parte importante en el crecimiento de este negocio y ayuda a mejorar la calidad de vida de esta familia, muchas gracias.

loans.use: Purchase imitation jewelery  raw material

loans.name: Danelia Del Carmen

texts.es:
Hello, my name is Danelia del Carmen. I am a merchant and I own a small business where I sell cosmetics, lotions, and fashion jewelry, which I distribute as an ambulant vendor. I have done this for several years, and it generates the income I need to cover the family expenses and pay my vendors. At this moment, I'd like to better stock my business and offer a larger variety of products to my customers. Most of them are school teachers and office workers. The better assorted by business is, the better the sales and income will be.

Translated by Raón F. Kolb, Kiva Volunteer.

Original description in Spanish:

Hola mi nombre es Danelia del Carmen, soy comerciante, cuento con un pequeño negocio de venta de cosmeticos, lociones y enchape, los que distribuyo de manera ambulante, tengo varios años de dedicarme a este tipo de negocio, el que me genera ingresos para cubrir los gastos de mi familia y otros compromisos con los proveedores, actualmente necesito surtir mas mi negocio y poder ofrecer mayor variedad de productos a mis clientes, considerando que la mayoria de mis clientes son maestros y empleados de oficina. considerando que entre mas surtido esta el negocio mayores son las ventas y por ende los ingresos.

loans.use: Purchase of lotions, cosmetics, and fashion jewelry

loans.name: Suja'i

texts.id:
Suja’i lives in a rented place for Rp150,000.00 (about US$16.50)/month. He lives with his wife and 5 children. The eldest is 11 years old. He works as a recycler with his wife. They have been in this business for one year. They chose a pick up truck to pick up the items to be recycled around the city of Denpasar, hotels that has been their customers. In the morning they go around town to pick up these items. In the afternoon they brought those items home, sorted according to type, and weigh them. Afterwards they bring those items to the place to sell: Mentasari street, not too far from where they live. This business could bring a profit of Rp3,000,000 (about $330)/month. Their living expenses are about Rp50,000 (about $5.50)/day, and children's education expenses of about Rp200,000.00 (about $22)/month, have made them to work hard. That is their daily work. Suja’i and wife have high hopes for the expected capital. This capital will help them to obtain more to be recycled goods to buy and store. The higher the capital, the higher the profit to be achieved. Their children's future depends on this business.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Suja’i tinggal di tempat kos dengan satu kamar seharga Rp 150.000,00/bulan. Sudah lima tahun dia tinggal tempat yang sekarang ini. Dia tinggal bersama isteri dan 5 orang anaknya. Anaknya yang sulung berumur 11 tahun. Dia bekerja sebagai pemulung bersama isterinya. Mereka menekuni usaha ini baru sekitar satu tahun. Mereka memilih sebuah mobil pick up untuk mengambil barang-barang rongsokan di sekitar Kota Denpasar, yaitu hotel – hotel yang sudah menjadi langganannya. Pada pagi hari mereka keliling untuk mengambil barang-barang rongsokan. Dan siang harinya mereka bawa pulang untuk dipilih dan dikumpulkan sesuai dengan jenis barang lalu ditimbang. Setelah itu dibawa ke tempat penjualannya di Jl. Mertasari - tidak jauh dari tempat tinggal mereka. Usaha ini memberikan keuntungan mencapai Rp 3.000.000,00/bulan. Biaya hidup yang mencapai Rp 50.000,00/hari dan biaya pendidikan anak sebesar Rp 200.000,00/bulan membuat mereka harus bekerja dengan keras. Begitulah pekerjaan yang dilakukan sehari-hari. Suja’i dan isterinyanya berharap banyak dengan pinjaman yang mereka peroleh. Modal ini akan membantu mereka untuk lebih banyak memperoleh barang rongsokan untuk dibeli dan dikumpulkan. Semakin besar modal yang mereka miliki, akan semakin besar pula keuntungan yang akan mereka dapat. Masa depan anak – anak mereka bergantung pada usaha ini.

loans.use:
To buy items to be recycled

Membeli barang - barang rongsokan

loans.name: Sénadé

texts.fr:
Mrs. Sénadé A. K. was born in 1972 in Agomé-Glozou where she is presently living. She is responsible for six persons. Her husband is a teacher and also helps earn the family's living. Unfortunately, Mrs. A. K. does not have enough business capital to be able to satisfy the demands of her customers. Her business is buying and selling bulk quantities of palm nuts for processing. She brings her baskets, bowls and sacks to the women who produce palm oil to purchase palm nuts and send them off to Lomé for resale. After 10 years of being in this business of which she knows all the ins and outs, she needs additional capital so that she can purchase and resell larger quantities. For this reason, she is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 500. The increased income will allow her to improve living conditions for her family and provide for her children's education.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Madame Sénadé A. K. est née en 1972 à Agomé-glozou où elle vit encore avec six (06) personnes à sa charge. Son mari, instituteur contribue aux charges du ménage. Néanmoins, les fonds de commerce de Sénadé A. K. ne lui permettent pas de satisfaire sa clientèle. La vente des noix palmistes aux unités industrielles de transformation est son activité. Elle se promène, paniers, bols et sacs auprès des femmes productrices de l’huile de palme pour acheter ses noix et les achemine sur Lomé pour la vente. Connaissant aujourd’hui tous les rouages de cette activité après dix (10) ans d'expérience, elle nécessite les fonds afin d’augmenter sa capacité d’achat et de vente. Elle compte saisir cette opportunité pour solliciter un crédit de $500. Les revenus lui serviront à améliorer les conditions de vie et d’étude de ses enfants.

loans.use:
Bulk purchase and resale of palm nuts

Achat en quantité et vente de noix de palmistes

loans.name: Ghazala

texts.en: I am 30, married and a mother of four: two boys and two girls. I live with my family in the second largest city of Pakistan—Lahore. My husband is a carpenter, and he manufactures very beautiful furniture out of wood.  We have previously acquired a few loans for this business, which translated into increased income. I stay at home, and along with my household chores, I make comforters for my neighborhood clients. Now my husband requires another loan of $350 to invest in his business and buy wood in a large quantity.

loans.use: Needs a loan to buy wood

loans.name: Teresa José David

texts.pt:
Teresa José David L. is married with 5 children. She entered the program in 2006 with a loan of 3000MT. She is a farmer and has a sales stand in her house. She is asking for a loan of $275.00US to be paid back in 4 months so that she can enroll her children in school.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer

Teresa José David L., Portadora do BI nº100137760S Vive maritalmente tem 5 filhos entrou no programa em 2006 tomando o valor de 3000 mt é agricultora e tem uma barraca em sua casa ogra vai tomar 6000 a pagar em 4 meses o valor é para fazer a matricula dos seus filhos.

loans.use: Enroll her children in school

loans.name: Dadzo

texts.fr:
Dadzo D. (the woman with her hand on the sandalettes) is 43 years old, married, and the mother of three. Her husband is inactive, and she provides for the family by the income that she earns from selling sandalettes (flip-flops) at the Adeta marketplace and surrounding villages. With the present loan, she is going to increase her inventory in order to satisfy her customers better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

Mme Dadzo D. (femme ayan posé ses mains sur les sandalettes) est âgée de 43 ans, mariée et mère de trois enfants . Son mari est inactif et elle subvient aux besoins de la famille Par le revenu qu’elle tire de la vente des sandalettes au marché d’Adéta et dans ses villages environnants. Avec le présent emprunt elle va augmenter son stock afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.

loans.use: To buy flip-flops in Lomé and resell them in Adéta

loans.name: Vencedoras Group

texts.en:
“Vencedoras” is a small rural community bank of FINCA Peru’s Wari-project which provides its credit with educational services in the rural areas of Huancavelica. Huancavelica is considered one of the poorest regions of Peru and has many limitations, being a very mountainous area (altituD. ranges from 6,000 – 17,000 ft above sea level). People there have to contend with the cold, difficulty growing crops, and the lack of an adequate infrastructure of roads and communication systems.

Community Bank “Vencedoras” is located in the community of Locroja in the district with the same name, and province of Churcampa. The main activities of the population are growing corn (lower altitudes), potatoes and wheat (higher altitudes) and raising cows and bulls, guinea-pigs, pigs, and chickens.

Currently this community bank has completed its first loan-cycle and just half a year of existence with 11 female borrowers and a total loan of 2,500 soles (about US$ 900). The individual loans range from 100, 200, up to 300 soles. Besides repaying their loans, the group was able to save over 2,100 soles (about US$ 750) during their first loan-cycle and will continue to save in the future. For all members, the main use of the savings is for investing in their business or for the education of their children: to buy school uniforms, supplies, books, and even to pay for entering primary or secondary school.

During their first loan-cycle, the members have learned many things: to be responsible, to save for future investment, and have received training in a variety of issues. Another thing they like is practicing values like punctuality, responsibility and solidarity.

One of the group members, Nieves Aurora B. A., sells vegetables, fruit, and clothes. To earn a little more money, she also raises guinea-pigs and pigs. With her 300 soles loan, she will buy new supplies for her small business. When asked about her future, she tells us that her main dream is for her family to have a better quality of life, that she will be saving for the education of her children so they can be professionals, keep studying, and maybe in the future, even work for an institution like FINCA. What she has learned until now in FINCA is to give a name to her savings, making it easier to save more because she knows exactly why she is saving.

Ana Marcela B., who has a small grocery store in the community and also sells clothes tells a slightly different story. With her loan of 300 soles, she will be also able to buy more supplies for her store. Her dream for the future is for her children to study and become professionals. Besides that, she wishes to move to the city of Huancayo and build a house there, where she can have a bigger store and earn more. With her savings she wants to buy more supplies. In FINCA she has learned to respect and to be respected by the others, and has learned to save.

loans.use: purchasing new supplies for their various small businesses

loans.name: Mujeres En Pregreso Group

texts.es:
This partnership from the neighbourhood of Santo Domingo emerged when the members of another group from the same neighbourhood broke up. The majority of the members formed a new group. They have held the necessary meetings for the formation of a partnership. It is currently made up of fifteen hardworking women involved in the following activities: food preparation, hairdressing, sale of clothing, other retail businesses such as groceries, food, natural remedies, vegetables, baked goods, clothing, the raising of poultry, etc. Each group member receives an average of 300,000 Gs that she reinvests by buying merchandise or ingredients for making various products to sell.

These women are real go-getters. As well as running their businesses, they are also wives and mothers.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer.

Este comité del Barrio Santo Domingo ha surgido por medio de las integrantes de otro comité del mismo Barrio el cual se ha desintegrado, pero la mayoría de sus integrantes formaron un nuevo comité. Se han realizado las reuniones requeridas para la conformación y actualmente el comité esta integrado por 15 mujeres trabajadoras. Las actividades de estas señoras consisten en: comedores, peluquería, venta de ropas, Venta de mercaderías varias, venta de comestibles, venta de remedos naturales, venta de verduras, repostería, venta de ropas, cría de pollos y otros. Cada integrante recibe en promedio la suma de 300.000 Gs. que lo reinvierten comprando mercaderías o insumos para la elaboración de sus productos a vender.

Estas son mujeres luchadoras que además de llevar adelante sus negocios, también deben cumplir sus roles de madres y esposas en sus hogares.

loans.use: To purchase clothing, hair products, ingredients for the preparation of food, flour, baking products, canned goods, rice, noodles, drinks, baby chicks, natural medicines, ingredients for cakes, etc.

loans.name: Sabina Dudu's Group

texts.en:
Sabina is leader of a group with four members. She is 30 years old and divorced with three children aged 15, 12, and 8 years. All of them go to school. The community she resides and works in is semi-urban and surrounded by slums.

She washes, dyes, and plaits hair. She has been providing these services for seven years in Lusaze, one of the suburbs of Kampala. Her clients are residents of the nearby slums.

She faces stiff competition, which forces her to charge low fees, and sometimes she inadvertently buys fake materials, which causes her to lose money. Another challenge is the seasonality of her market. The months of January, February, July, August, and September are slow for her business because her clients pay school dues in these months.

She acquired a plot of land in Lusaze with the loan she got from MCDT and is looking after her family. She would like to construct a house in the near future.

Sabina has successfully paid back five loans.

loans.use: To increase her stock of salon accessories

loans.name: Yawo

texts.fr:
Mr. Yawo M. was born on September 9, 1970 in Lomé. He is a bachelor and lives in the Hédzranawoé neighborhood in Lomé. He retails electrical goods next to the service station that is located near the market of Hédzranawoé. His plan is to equip a store where he can keep his goods, so he won't have to bring things back and forth every day. He has already reimbursed one loan correctly.

In order to realize his little project, he is asking for this second loan to outfit a store he has rented and buy 20 cases of electrical wire and 10 cases of switches.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Monsieur M. Yawo est né le 09 septembre 1970 à Lomé. Il est célibataire et réside dans le quartier Hédzranawoé à Lomé. Il est revendeur de matériels d’électricité à côté de la station d’essence située à côté du marché de Hédzranawoé. Son projet est d’aménager un magasin pouvant lui permettre de stocker ses matériels et d’éviter des allers-retours à la fin de chaque journée. Il a une fois bénéficié du crédit et a bien remboursé.

Pour la réalisation de son petit projet, il sollicite ce deuxième crédit pour faire l’aménagement d’un magasin qu’il a loué et acheter 20 cartons de fil électrique et 10 cartons de réglette.

loans.use:
Purchase of electrical goods

Achat de matériels électriques

loans.name: Miriam Janet

texts.es:
Miriam Janet is 36 years old and is married. She studied up through 3 years of high school. She has one daughter still dependent on her and lives in the district of Victor Larco Province of Trujillo, La Libertad.

In order to earn a living, she sells beauty products, and is a childcare provider (runs a daycare) for a group of children under 5 years of age, for parents who work outside their home. She runs the daycare during the day, and in the evening, she travels throughout her district to visit her clients wishing to purchase beauty products. She is interested in obtaining the awards for sales and customer retention.

The first loan she received was S/.300.00, which she invested in the purchase of cosmetic products that were on sale, and was then able to sell them at a higher price and increase her profits. Miriam Janet belongs to the Communal Bank "Las Palmeras". With this new loan of S/.800.00, which she plans on repaying within 6 months, she plans on buying additional products to increase her inventory and make more money. Miriam also dreams of building her house someday.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Miriam Janet está casada, tiene 36 años, estudió hasta 3er año de secundaria, tiene 01 hija la que todavía depende de ella. Vive en el distrito de Víctor Larco Provincia de Trujillo, La Libertad . Actualmente se dedica a vender productos de belleza de diferentes líneas y a la vez es madre cuidadora en un wawawasi (cuidado de niños); tiene a su cargo un grupo de niños menores de 5 años a los cuales cuida, estimula y atiene mientras sus padres salen a trabajar. Durante las tardes sale por todo su distrito a visitar a sus clientas para vender sus productos de belleza ya que le interesa obtener los premios por ventas y captación de clientas. El primer préstamo que recibió fue de S/.300.00, los cuales invirtió en la compra de productos cosméticos que estaban en promoción para luego venderlos a mayor precio e incrementar su ganancia. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “LAS PALMERAS”, con el préstamo de S/.800.00, que cancelará en un plazo de 06 meses comprará productos para incrementar su stock y pueda realizar ventas al crédito. La Señora Miriam sueña con construir su casa.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products (Compra de productos de belleza.)

loans.name: Karla Vanessa

texts.es:
Young Karla Vanessa is requesting refinancing of her 6th loan in order to invest the money in improvements to her home. She will finish plastering the walls. She has worked as a teacher for 8 years. Karla does not have children but she has taken on responsibility for the care of her elderly parents and for the family's living expenses. She is a responsible, honest, hardworking young woman who is beloved in her community. She lives in the Bellezas area, 2 kilometers from Triunfo, in Nueva Guinea. Karla is a teacher who loves her work since she helps many rural children from her area. She is currently in her 4th year at the university URACCAN Recinto Nueva Guinea. She feels grateful for AFODENIC; with her previous loans she purchased appliances and improved her home. Her dream is to have a pretty home and steady work with which she can help her mother with the household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La Joven Karla Vanessa está solicitando refinanciamiento de su 6to crédito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda (terminar de repellar las paredes de su vivienda), trabaja como docente desde hace 8 años. Karla no tiene hijos, pero se encarga del cuido de sus ancianos padres, ella asume los gastos familiares, es una joven responsable, honesta, trabajadora y muy querida en su comunidad; vive en la comarca las Bellezas a 2 km del Truinfo en Nueva Guinea. Karla es una docente que ama su trabajo ya que ayuda a muchos niños campesinos de su comarca, actualmente está estudiando su 4to año en la universidad URACCAN Recinto Nueva Guinea. Ella se siente agradecida con la Institución de AFODENIC, pues con los créditos anteriores ha comprado electrodomésticos y a mejorado la vivienda donde ella vive, su mayor sueño es tener una vivienda bonita y trabajo para ayudar a su madre con los gastos del hogar.

loans.use: Plaster the walls of her home.

loans.name: Phan Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Phan Thi H. joined TYM Fund in 2005. At present she lives with her husband and two children in Hung Nguyen district, Nghe An commune. Her family's main source of income is their restaurant. For 2 years in TYM, Mrs. H. has complied with TYM's regulations very well and repaid her loans in a timely fashion. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 9 million to buy a cow and raise it for sale.

loans.use: buy a cow to raise for sale

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Mrs. Meas K. is a farmer in Boeng Kranh Village in the Takeo Province. Her husband, Mr. Un Sorn, uses his motorbike to carry a cart which is used to transport goods and passengers for a fee. Mrs. Meas K. is 50-years-old and the mother of four children. Two are employed in a garment factory while the remaining two are enrolled in the local school.

Although Mrs. Meas K.'s family members are employed in different businesses, they still cannot support their family. Mrs. Meas K. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase her income after she sells that cow. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Domingo

texts.es: DOMINGO ES CASADO, LA FAMILIA COMPONE DE 3 HIJOS DE 6, 16 Y 18 AÑOS, TODOS SOLTEROS, CON RESIDENCIA EN MINERO. SUS ACTIVIDADES SON COMERCIO DE COMIDAS Y RENTA DE MOTOTAXI, LA MISMA CUENTA CON MUCHOS AÑOS DE EXPERIENCIA EN EL RUBRO,  TIENE POCA COMPETENCIA EN LA ZONA., EL DESTINO DEL CREDITO ES PARA COMPRA DE MOTO. PARA HACER TRABAJAR Y PERCIBIR RENTA DEL MISMO, EL CLIENTE TIENE BUEN HISTORICO CON NUESTRA INSTITUCION, NO TIENE DEUDA DIRECTA O INDIRECTA CON OTRAS INSTITUCIONES.
texts.en:
Domingo is married, his family made up of 3 children aged 6, 16 and 18 years of age, and all of whom are single. They live in Minero. His business is selling prepared foods and passenger transport, having many years experience in each, and has very little competition in the region. This loan is destined to purchase a motorcycle, to put to use and to rent it out. This client has a good past history with the institution, having no outstanding debts with this or other institutions.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle.

loans.name: Geronimo

texts.en:
Geronimo is a simple farmer with simple dreams – to uplift their economic life and send their children to school with the help of his industrious wife.  He is married to Marina, who works as a vendor in their village.  Their inspirations in life are their two children: John Paul – 10 years old, grade IV elementary student and John Henry – 4 years old.
 
Farming has been their major source of income.  Geronimo produces rice every three to four months He earns a net income between PHP10,000 to PHP15,000 every harvest season.  Because of the expensive farm inputs, traders buy their rice products at a lower price. Because of this, he requests a loan of PHP18,000 to support his farming business and to avoid asking credits from traders with higher interest.  He is grateful that he was able to borrow from lenders that offers small interest and creates better opportunities in their lives - thus, helps their family to be free from poverty.  
	
Geronimo said that through prayers and hard work, his dreams can be achieved someday.  Providing his children their right to education is one of the important things that Geronimo prioritizes.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Khol's Group

texts.en:
This small loan is going to three borrowers, all residents of Phnom Penh City. The group leader, Mrs. Khol S., is 47 years old and earns a living by providing cookery products, including pans and dishes, using her own truck as transport from market to market in and around Cambodia. She currently earns an income approximately of US$ 8 per day, and she has been running her business for more than one year.

She is married with two children: one is single and one is married and also works with her in the business. Her husband is a local construction worker as well as helping with her business. To enlarge her investment, S. has requested a loan to purchase a range of cookery products to sell.

The two other borrowers are:

Toem C., 40, a grocery market seller who is applying for a loan to buy more groceries for re-sale.

Khol R., 32, who sells groceries from her home and is requesting a loan to repair her old house.

loans.use: to purchase a range of cookery products

loans.name: Rosa  De Los Angeles

texts.es:
Rosa de los Ángeles P. M. tiene la edad de 49 años, su estado civil es casada, Doña Rosa tiene 2 hijos sus edades son las siguientes su hijo menor de 21 años de edad cursa el 3 año de su carrera en una universidad publica y su hijo mayor de 22 años cursa el 4 año de su carrera, su compañero de vida labora como profesor, sus propósitos son de seguir manteniendo su clientela ya que son la fuente de ingresos necesarias con la que cuentan, sus deseos son de que sus hijos terminen de estudiar los estudios universitarios ya que es importante ya que le servirán en un futuro para obtener un trabajo en el que puedan desempeñarse, sus sueños son de que cuando se encuentre en una edad mas avanzada sus hijos logren hacerse cargo de ella ya que la mayoría de hijos no quieren hacerse cargo de sus Madres.

La actividad económica a la que se dedica es la venta de mercadería en general como: ropa, cosméticos y calzado, la ubicación de su negocio es de manera ambulante, el tiempo que tiene de poseer su negocio es de 3 años, Doña Rosa inicia este negocio en busca de otro trabajo que le generara ingresos para su familia  por lo que decidió dedicarse a la venta de mercadería por lo que al comienzo no le fue tan difícil ya que siempre le ha gustado trabajar para responsabilizarse con su familia razón por la que decide comenzar este negocio ella dio inicio con pocos productos como: ropa para niños, faldas y pantalones y así recurre a todas sus amistades que para mostrarles los productos de venta además empezó a realizar los financiamientos con el fin de invertir mas en su mercadería por lo que siempre ha trabajado con Fundación y decidió quedarse con este apoyo, el financiamiento es para capital de trabajo destinado para ropa interior, perfumes y uniformes ya que las compras las realiza en Managua y así tendría lo suficiente para ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Rosa de los Ángeles P. M. is 49 years old, married, and has two children. Her youngest is 21 years old and is in his third year at a public university, her eldest is 22 years old and in his fourth year. Her life partner works as a professor. Rosa's goals are to maintain her clientele, as they are the source of the income she relies on. She wants her children to finish their studies so that they will be able to find jobs in the future where they can be successful. She hopes that when she gets older her children will be able to care for her, unlike the majority of children who don't want to be responsible for their mothers. Rosa works as a street vendor selling general merchandise such as clothing, cosmetics, and footwear. She has had this business for three years. Rosa began this business in search of another job that could generate income for her family. She decided to sell merchandise because it was not very difficult in the beginning and she had always liked to work and to be responsible for her family. She began with a small amount of merchandise: clothing for children, skirts, and pants. She turned to all of her friends, showing them what she had for sale, and began to earn money and re-invest in more merchandise. She has always worked with Kiva partner Fundación Leon 2000 and has decided to stay with them. The loan is to provide capital to buy underclothes, perfumes, and uniforms. These purchases must be made in Managua, and the loan will allow her to have enough to offer her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Martyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital to buy merchandise

loans.name: Rogelia

texts.es:
Antes que tuviera hijos, Rogelia se dedicó a variados tipos de trabajos, el último de ellos fue como empleada en una tienda de ropa. Dejó de trabajar cuando tuvo su primer hijo, hace quince años. No obstante, hace tres, cuando nació su tercer y último hijo, se dio cuenta que de alguna manera tenía que apoyar los ingresos de su esposo para cubrir los gastos del hogar y de la familia.
Entonces empezó con su negocio de venta de ropa y zapatos. Hasta ahora le ha ido bastante bien, y tuvo ocasión de agrandarlo aún más cuando empezó a recibir préstamos de EDAPROSPO. Las ganancias de su negocio las utiliza para cubrir los gastos que su esposo no alcanza, y las demás las reinvierte en mercancía.
A sus treinta y un años le gustaría, en un futuro, poder juntar un poco de dinero para alquilar un local y abrir una tienda de ropa en el centro de Lima, ya que en Puente Piedra no hay mucha salida de comercio.
texts.en:
Before she had children, Rogelia had a variety of jobs, the last of which was as an employee in a clothing store. She left that job when she had her first child 15 years ago. Nevertheless, three years ago when her third and last child was born, she realized that she had to, in some way, support her husband’s income to cover the household and family expenses. So she began a business selling clothing and shoes. Up until now it has gone rather well, and she had the opportunity to expand her business even more when she began to receive EDAPROSPO loans. The earnings from her business are used to cover the expenses her husband’s income can’t cover, and the rest is invested in merchandise. At 31 years old, she would like, in her future, to be able to save a little money to rent a locale and open a clothing store in Lima’s downtown, because in Puente Piedra there isn’t much commercial business.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in merchandise for her clothing and shoe business

loans.name: Mary Aoko

texts.en:
Mary Aoko O. is a 32 year old mother of two children, ages 6 and 4.5. Her husband works as an auto mechanic while Mary sells small fish called Omena. She started her business a long time ago and will use the loan to purchase more fish. One challenge she has faced lately is extending credit to customers who do not pay her back.

Mary recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a community health worker, she will be trained by K-MET and will then begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her volunteer work will include distributing Nutriflour (vitamin-enriched flour) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: Purchase fish for resale

loans.name: La Bendicion 5 Group

texts.en:
The members of La Bendicion 5 Group have been clients of Esperanza International for 3 years, and are starting their 6th loan cycle. Many of the five members of this group sell clothes. They have made enough sales to successfully pay back five loans and have made profits that helped them to improve their quality of life. Each member sells in a different place and they refer customers to one another if a customer is looking for a specific item someone else in the group has for sale.

Ana R. is the group representative. She is a mother of 5 children. Selling clothes allows her to have her own income without leaving her home for extended periods at a time. The loans she has taken out have enabled her to purchase merchandise in larger quantities and of better quality. This has resulted in a faithful clientele that has grown thanks to her customers' referrals. Ana believes her hard work will pay off and one day she will have her own boutique.

Please help us to continue supporting these entrepreneurs through Kiva loans. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase new clothing items for resale.

loans.name: Amgalan

texts.en:
Amgalan A., a 43-year-old married mother of one son attending elementary school, lives with her family in a "ger" (a nomadic Mongolian tent) in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. In 2004, after having worked for a tailoring company for 16 years, she and her husband Tugsbileg started a family tailoring business, beginning with one sewing machine and 300,000 tugrugs ($1.00 USD=1450 MNT) in working capital. Amgalan gained many repeat clients in a short period of time because of her quality work, and as the number of her clients increased, she hired a tailor and bought another sewing machine. Her business capital has increased to 1,200,000 tugrugs, and average monthly income has reached 750,000 tugrugs.

With this loan, Amgalan will buy a cloth-cutting machine. Her dream is to help her son attain a quality education and be a good person.

loans.use: To buy a cloth-cutting machine

loans.name: Margarette Younas Masih Group

texts.en:
My name is Margarette and I've been a citizen of Lahore, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Lahore is famous for its Punjabi foods and for its historical places. My husband's name is Y. M.. He works in a factory on a monthly wage. My husband’s income is insufficient to meet our expenses which allows me to operate my beauty salon. I have been running my salon for the past three years. I have a good number of customers. I am applying for a loan to buy supplies, such as cosmetics and a dryer machine, for my beauty salon.

I am the leader of a group of three other women from my locality. Nargis baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics to sell. Shazia baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes-selling business. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy supplies for a beauty salon

loans.name: Hem's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of three people. Its leader, Mr. Hem S., is age 47 and he lives with his wife and their six children. He makes a living selling various grocery products, such as cooking ingredients, plastic products, and sweets (candies). He has operated this business since 1985, and currently earns approximately $4 per day.

On the other hand, he and his wife also cultivate a rice crop during the farming season. Hem S. is applying for a loan to spend on plowing his own farmland and to buy additional grocery inventory to sell.

The other two borrowers are:

Mr. N. is a firewood seller, who is seeking for a loan to plow a field in order to grow a crop.

Mrs. N. is a rice farmer, who requests a loan to begin raising pigs.

They all live in the province of Kampong Chhnang.

loans.use: To plow his farmland and buy additional groceries to sell

loans.name: Mora

texts.en:
Mora J. is currently in the business of selling bread and charcoal and is requesting a loan to open up a bakery. Mora is 27 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has 1 child and her child goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open up a bakery.

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es: Rosa María Juárez M. tiene 59 años de edad. Es una mujer casada. Tiene 3 hijos a su cargo. Su actividad económica es la venta y destace de cerdo. Hace más de 30 años que se dedica a este negocio. Ella inicia este negocio pensando en el bienestar de sus hijos, la idea surgió por una amiga ya que ella le dio la sugerencia, de que se dedicara a este tipo de negocio a la venta de cerdos y con ella asistía a las comarcas para realizar la venta de ellos, con el paso del tiempo fue que decide realzar el destace de cerdo, por lo que la elaboración de los nacatamales no era tan fácil, pero con la ayuda de su amiga aprendió la Elaboración de los nacatamales. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de cerdos y materia prima como masa, e ingredientes entre otras cosas. Su deseo es comprar los suficientes cerdos para obtener más ingresos.
texts.en:
Rosa María Juárez M. is 59 years old. She is married, and has 3 children. Her economic activity for more than 30 years has been selling pork. She started her business thinking about the well-being of her children, and the idea arose because of a friend’s suggestion. Together, they visited the villages to sell their product. Over time, she learned how to butcher the pigs and how to make nacatamales (a local dish) from her friend. The loan she requests is for working capital to buy pigs and dough, ingredients, and other items. Her wish is to buy enough pigs to generate more income.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David W. is a 46-year-old businessman, married to one wife with whom he has three children. His primary business is being a wholesale and retail supplier of potatoes, cabbages, peas, tomatoes and onions in the Kangemi Market near Nairobi. He has been in the business for the past 17 years and is now able to make a monthly profit of about 45,000 Kenyan shillings (about $550).   

David plans to use this loan to boost his primary business and to invest in the timber business. This will be his sixth loan from KADET. Before getting financing from KADET, he never borrowed from another financial institution.

David aspires to expand and grow his business so as to be able to achieve his goals, such as buying a plot of land, building a good permanent house and educating his children to the highest level.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for a wholesale produce business, and to invest in timber sales

loans.name: Lugendo Namuwaya Mary Group

texts.en: Mary N. is twenty-three years of age. She is a single mother blessed with three children and one dependent going to school. She is a tailor and she has been tailoring for over four years. She will use the loan to purchase material for making dresses, uniforms, and so forth for her customers. Her business makes it possible for her to purchase what she wants. She is a hardworking business lady whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase material for making dresses, uniforms, etc.

loans.name: Mitsi

texts.en:
Mitsi D. V. is 26 years old and is married with one child.  She and her husband work together in the timber business.  They live in the city of Pucallpa.  

Mitsi has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about a year and a half and is a member of the communal bank “Las Triunfadoras” (The Winners).  She invested her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100) in the sale of condiments, a business that she had at that time.  Nowadays, Mitsi is working full time with her husband in the timber business.  She will use this loan of 1700 soles to purchase wood at Pucallpa’s port along the Ucayali, a wide brown river that flows past the city and eventually joins the Amazon to the north.  Mitsi and her husband process the wood into boards.  

Mitsi’s goal is to purchase a planer and another machine for the small sawmill that she and her husband have been operating for the past 6 months.  In this way she hopes to offer better service to their customers.

loans.use: Wood for a sawmill business.

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.es:
Feliciana tiene 40 años, es una mujer muy alegre, vive en su casa propia con su esposo y sus hijos, que son el motivo de su esfuerzo. Ella es una persona muy emprendedora, sobre todo inclinada al comercio, ya que le gusta mucho conversar y hacer amistad con toda la gente. Su ocupación principal es la venta de frutas, lo hace todos los fines de semana en el mercado de su localidad, donde ha hecho mucha clientela y le va muy bien. Por otro lado, al ver la carencia de papelerías en su pueblo decidió implementar en su casa una pequeña librería llamada “Mananquiari” (nombre de su pueblo) y en el mismo ambiente vende algunas golosinas y productos que le solicitan sus clientes. A esta tienda se dedica de lunes a viernes y los fines de semana, mientras ella vende sus frutas, su esposo y su hija se quedan a cargo de la tienda, de ese modo, genera mayores ingresos económicos para la familia. 
Este su tercer préstamo con MFP y está predispuesta para pagar puntualmente sus cuotas como en sus créditos anteriores, además es la presidenta de su banco comunal y quiere ser ejemplo de responsabilidad. El dinero que viene solicitando lo piensa invertir en la compra de láminas ilustrativas didácticas, las cuales son muy demandadas por los niños para sus tareas escolares.
texts.en:
Feliciana, 40, is a very happy woman. She lives in her own house with her husband and their children. They are the reason for her efforts. She is a very enterprising woman. Above all, she is inclined towards commerce. She likes to chat a lot and make friends with people. Her primary occupation is selling fruit, which she does every week end in the town market. She has gained many customers, and it is going very well. Upon seeing the lack of stationery stores in her village, she decided to set up a small stationery store called “Manaquiari” (the name of her village) in her house. In the store she also sells sweets and other products her customers ask for. She works in the store Monday through Friday. On the week ends, while she is selling fruit, her husband and daughters are in charge of the store. This way they generate more income for the family. This is her third loan with MFP. She is prepared to make her payments punctually as she did with her previous loans. She is the president of her communal bank, and she wants to be an example of responsibility. The money she is asking for is to buy laminated educational sheets, which are in great demand by children to do their homework.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Monika

texts.en: Monika C. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at the resturant  and is requesting a loan to purchase  more foodstuffs and tables .  Monika is 30 years old and is Married with a husband that is a business man. She has 1 child and her child goes to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for family settlement BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more foodstuffs and tables

loans.name: Leslie Del Carmen

texts.es: Doña Leslie de 46 años de edad es soltera, sus hijos ya son mayores y son independientes, se recibio de abogada pero no esta ejerciendo totalmente su carrera, pues se dedica la mayor parte del tiempo a administrar una pequeña tienda que tiene en su casa de habitacion ubicada en Cuapa, Chontales.  Esta solicitando su 3er credito para comprar mercaderia e invertir en su tienda, vende ropa, cosmeticos y articulos que le encargan sus clientes.  Expresa se siente muy agradecida con los financiamientos que AFODENIC le ha brindado, pues con estos ha podido incrementar poco a poco su negocio, aunque ahora logre ser beneficiada con el fondo Kiva que apoya a las personas que desean superarse.
texts.en:
Mrs. Leslie is 46 years old. She is single and has grown-up children who are independent. She has a law degree but is not using it fully. She dedicates the majority of her time to manage a small store she has in her house in Cuapa Chontales. She is asking for her third loan to buy merchandise and invest in her store. She sells clothes, cosmetics, and other products her customers order. She is very grateful for the financing AFODENIC has provided since it's allowed her to grow her business little by little. Now she is a beneficiary of Kiva, which supports people who want to better themselves.

Translated from Spanish by Lydia Brantley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Clothing and cosmetic store

loans.name: Tereza

texts.en:
Tereza T. is currently in the business of selling charcoal out of her home and is requesting a loan to purchase beans and onions to sell. Tereza is 37 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant . She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase beans and onions to sell

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 32 years old and married with a two-year-old son. He has a shoe shop where he sells new and old shoes. He’s run this business for seven years and has one employee. Moses is requesting a loan for Kes 70,000 to increase his inventory.

Moses says that since joining Faulu, he has learnt about how to save and manage his business. He describes himself as determined, visionary, and cooperative. In the future, he would like to buy a plot of land and build a home for his family and expand his business into a large shoe store.

loans.use: To add to his stock of shoes

loans.name: Eteli

texts.en:
Eteli F. is a 49-year-old woman living in the town of Asau. She is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Eteli owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Eteli has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 400 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Eteli joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eteli has successfully repaid a previous loan of 750 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Eteli is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Eteli plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Va

texts.en:
Va F. is 23 and married with 2 children (ages 1 and 3).  She is starting a business venture, planting & harvesting fruits & vegetables for sale.  Va  needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 200 tala or US $83 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Va  joined SPBD. This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Va 's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Va F. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.78 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375p

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en: Emelia G. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 32 years old. Emelia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Emelia operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling different goods such as coffee, milk, canned goods and, primarily, rice. Emelia sells a variety of rice per kilo or per sack in the local community. Emelia has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Emelia joined HSPFI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Emelia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Emelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Soy

texts.en: Mrs. Soy K. is 61 years old and she lives in Spueu village, Takeo province. She is married, with three children who are all employed in the garment factory. Mrs. Soy K. and her husband, Mr. Phart Keit, are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare field for cultivating rice. In this plantation, they do not have cows to support their field crop, so Mrs. Soy K. is requesting a loan to buy two oxen for plowing and supporting their farming. Her husband is on the left of the picture.

loans.use: To buy two oxen

loans.name: Karina Evelyn

texts.es: La Sra. Karina vive en anticretico que son propietarios sus papas ubicado en la zona de Quintanilla , tiene como actividad economica la venta de ropa , carteras , zapatos y otros al contado y a credito , generalmente entrega a empresas , instituciones , colegios y otros. no cuenta con tienda ni puesto de venta ella realiza su mercaderia ambulando y ofreciendo puerta a puerta. La cliente es de clase media y sencilla, se tiene buena referencia  por clientes de nuestra institucion. Ella es concubina y tiene dos hijitos pequeños por quienes trabaja bastante para poder sacar a sus hijos adelante ya que sola mantiene a sus hijos porque su pareja se encuentra sin trabajo por el momento, ella es muy trabajadora y con dinero del credito comprara mercaderia y asi poder incrementar su capital de trabajo, esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Karina lives in Anticretico on her parents’ land located in the Quintanilla zone. She sells clothing, wallets, shoes, and other items for cash and credit. She generally sells to people at their jobs, schools, and other places. She does not have a shop nor a stall anywhere; she sells door to door. Her customers are middle class and she has good references from our other clients. She cohabitates and has two small children for whom she works hard to get ahead. She provides the sole means of support for her children, because her partner is unemployed at the moment. She is a hard worker and will use the money from this loan to invest in merchandise and to increase her working capital. She is very grateful to Emprender and to Kiva for trusting her with this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory and working capital

loans.name: Adalua

texts.en:
Adalua A. is 28 years old and married to a policeman. She has three school-aged children. She is currently in the business of selling green vegetables at the market, and is requesting a loan to purchase fruits and vegetables to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, Adalua hopes to open a shop.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Pascaline

texts.fr: A. Pascaline est née en 1949 à Comé et s'est installée depuis une dizaine d'année au quartier Minontchou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Pascaline est une veuve et mère de trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Pascaline vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule les charges familiales. Pascaline n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Pascaline mène comme activité, la vente de divers produits (lait, savons, conserves de tomate et de sardine, bombons, biscuits, huile de palme et d'arachide, etc.) à son domicile. Pascaline s'approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Pascaline exerce cette activité depuis trente ans et a déjà obtenu cinq crédits auprès de ALIDé. Tous ces crédits ont tous été bien remboursés. Pascaline sollicite un autre prêt en vue d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux répondre à la demande nombreuse de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Pascaline A. was born in 1949 in Comé and settled some ten years ago in the Minontchou neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Pascaline is a widow and mother of three children, of which some have attended school. She lives alone with her children and is their sole provider. She has not been to school herself. To meet her needs Pascaline retails a range of products (milk, soap, canned tomatoes and sardines, candies, cookies, palm and peanut oil, etc.) from her home. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Pascaline has been in this line of business for the past 30 years and has already been granted five loans from ALIDé, all fully reimbursed. She is now requesting another loan to increase her stock of supplies and improve her response to numerous customer demands.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products (canned tomatoes and sardines, milk, soap, palm and peanut oil)

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora A. is from the village of Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 39 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Nora owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Nora has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Nora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Nora is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan she has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Maxmilla

texts.en:
Maxmilla M. M. runs two businesses in Nambale, Busia district. These two businesses are fish and grocery sales that she started in 2008 in one business stall. She buys her stock twice a week from the Nambale market. She is 21 years old, married and blessed with three children.

She would like a loan of 10,000 KES to expand her business. She believes in women's independence in the economy of today, and this is her dream.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Huong

texts.en: Huong T. T. N. was born in 1976. She lives in Luong Quy village, Xuan Non commune, Dong Anh district. She is married with three children. Her husband is a driver for a company near the house and has a monthly income. Mrs Huong has a store (she sells cakes, sweets, beer, etc). Besides the store, she is a tailor who makes clothes. Her family has a monthly income of about 7,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND).  She has participated in SEDA since 2006 and repaid punctually. For this loan, she wants to borrow 9,810,000 VND to expand her store and buy cloth to make clothes.

loans.use: To expand her store and buy cloth to make clothes.

loans.name: Arcilla

texts.en:
Arcilla V. is from the village of Hinaplanan, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 57 years old, married and has 2 grown children. To make a living, Arcilla owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Arcilla joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Arcilla is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Arcilla’s 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Luis Arcadio

texts.es:
Luis de 55 años, vive en una zona periurbana en la Perimetral de Guayaquil, solo cuenta con agua y luz como servicio básico. El tiene un camión y presta sus servicios para las cargas de productos o carnes que les pide sus clientes. 

El camión le ha ayudado a mantener a su familia durante mucho tiempo, trabaja desde las 07h00am hasta las 17h00pm todos los días. En ocasiones su hijo le ayuda cargando la mercadería para las empresas o a las personas que presta sus servicios. Para continuar con su camión necesita cambiar algunos repuestos por eso quiere comprar con el préstamo repuestos, y una cubierta para el piso del carro. 

En el futuro el quiere tener una línea de camiones dirigido a empresas.
texts.en:
Luis is fifty-five years old and lives in the suburbs of Guayaquil. He only has water and light for basic services. He has a truck he uses to transport products, meats, or whatever his customers need. His truck has helped him support his family for a long time. He works from seven in the morning until five in the afternoon. Sometimes his son helps him transport the merchandise for businesses or for the people who use his services. To continue with his truck, he needs to change some parts with the loan. He also wants to buy a cover for the floor of the truck. He would like to have a fleet of trucks geared toward businesses in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Car-parts and a cover

loans.name: Djado Jeanette

texts.en: Djado D. sells used clothing at the Hedzranawoe Market in Lome, Togo. She is 35 years old and married to another merchant. They have three children. Madame D. has been selling used clothing at the market for about 20 years. She has also been working with WAGES for some years. She has now requested her third loan from WAGES, of 500,000 West African CFA francs, in order to purchase more used clothing to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase used clothing to sell

loans.name: Djekabaara  3 Group

texts.fr:
Les  sept membres du groupe Djekabaara 3 sont  des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans, 3 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames à Sontiguila, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont  l’arachide, le petit mil et le haricot. Elles sont à leur premier prêt de campagne avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Avec ce prêt, SITAN C. compte acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 hectare d’arachide.
La production est vendue au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et dans la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée de revendeurs et consommateurs. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 50.000FCFA en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Djekabaara 3 group are married women, who average 35 years of age and have three children each; the majority of them live in polygamous families in Sontiguila, one of the villages of the prefecture of Dioïla, in the Koulikoro region, which is the second administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the aim of better organising their activities at the beginning of the winter season. The crops they cultivate are peanuts, pearl millet and beans. They are on their first farming loan from Soro Yiriwaso. With this loan, Sitan C. is planning to buy intrants before prices rise, and small equipment, as well as paying the labor costs to maintain around a hectare of peanuts. The produce, once harvested, is sold in the village of Nangola and the surroundings as well as in the town of Dioïla, to a customer base made up of retailers and consumers. The women are expecting to make an average profit of 50,000FCFA at the end of the season.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of intrants and small equipment as well payment of labor costs

loans.name: Teo

texts.en:
Teo is a widow with five children. Three of her children go to school, the others work at small jobs.  She own's a pub in Nalukolongo, selling all types of beer, local brew and gin.  She buys crates of beer from delivery vans and kegs of local brew from Ndeeba. Teo uses public transport to and from Ndeeba.  

Teo is going to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and kegs of local brew and gin.   She has done this business for six years and has been with MCDT for five years.  Besides this bar business she also owns a restaurant. She sells beer on a retail basis and she works seven days a week.  Her main challenge is that there are many bars around her area of operation. Teo aspires to see her business grow and start selling on wholesale basis only.  She decided to join MCDT because it was giving loans to women who live at the grass roots level.  She resides in and owns her house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her greatest  monthly expense in a month is food and school for her three children.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and kegs of local brew

loans.name: Marcosa

texts.en:
Marcosa P., and her husband James P., have six children.  Marcosa and James work hard to cover their daily expenses and put their children through school.  For the past five years Marcosa has been running a Sari-sari or general store in the market, which has provided earnings of 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. 

Marcosa would like to expand her store and increase her inventory, and has applied for a loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase soft drinks, meats, and dried fish.  She hopes the additional goods will allow her to generate more revenue and income.  

Marcosa has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since 2008 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.  She hopes she will eventually have a prosperous business.

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missionary work in a uniquely Filipino context.
