For this loan cycle, she hopes to borrow 9,000,000 VND to invest further in their fertilizer retail business to increase the family's income.

Translated from Vietnamese by Catherine Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest further into her fertilizer retail business

loans.name: Tului

texts.en: Tului E., 27, is married and has four children.  She has many years experience in the plantation business. She sells to the villagers and public people two days per week. Her husband is a very good carpenter, and his work supports the family and her business as well. This is Tului's first loan with SPBD, which is her only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.  She plans to purchase fertilizer, vegetable seeds, chemicals, and plastic bags for selling her plantation items.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer, vegetable seeds, chemicals, and plastic bags for selling plantation items.

loans.name: Anastasia

texts.es:
La señora Anastasia es socia del Banco Comunal “Sacuyo”, de la comunidad de Sacuyo, distrito de Acora, Provincia de Puno, Departamento de Puno; de  38 años de edad, tiene cinco  hijos, es casada y posee estudios de primaria completa.
Trabaja desde hace 6 meses con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos y se presto S/. 500.00 nuevos soles el cual le sirvió para trabajar en su tienda de abarrotes para ver sus ingresos creciendo y cumplir con su grupo.
Con este préstamo de S/.500.00 nuevos soles, el cual pagará en 3 cuotas, comprará más mercadería (saco de arroz, azúcar, cajas de atún, cajas de leche y otros) y de esta manera surtir mejor su negocio así poder tener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Anastasia is a member of the "Sacuyo" communal bank in the town of Sacuyo, district of Acora, Puno province. She is 38 years old, has five children, is married and completed primary school. She has worked with the Manuela Ramos movement for the past 6 months and was loaned S/. 500 new soles, which was used for her grocery store so that she could increase her income and meet her group commitments. With this loan for S/. 500 new soles, which will be repaid in 3 installments, she will buy more merchandise (sacks of rice, sugar, boxes of canned tuna, milk and other goods) and in this way better stock her business so that she can have more income.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a variety of products: rice, sugar, milk, etc.

loans.name: Dan

texts.es: Dan tiene 35 años de edad, vive con su esposa y su hijo, la casa donde viven es propia. Él brinda servicios de cabinas públicas de Internet, a razón de encontrarse cerca de una Institución Educativa porque sus principales clientes son los niños y jóvenes colegiales. Esta actividad la realiza desde hace 2 años atrás, administra y atiende su negocio él solo. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que se relaciona con los jóvenes quienes le piden su apoyo para cualquier tema a tratar. Le es muy rentable porque ya cuenta con su fiel clientela y sus cabinas funcionan diariamente. Posteriormente quiere ampliar y comprarse más computadoras, ya que las que tiene no abastece a muchos jóvenes que necesitan de este servicio. Con este son 9 préstamos que Dan ha trabajado con MFP, además que le gusta trabajar con su banco comunal. El dinero que solicita es para mandar a reparar sus computadoras, ya que tienen que estar en buenas condiciones para su uso diario.
texts.en:
Dan is 35 years old. He lives with his wife and his son in a house he owns. He offers internet access to the public. Because he is close to a school, most of his customers are children and young people who attend the school. He has had this business for two years: he manages and attends to his business alone. What he likes best about his work is interacting with the young people who ask for his help. The business is very profitable because he has loyal customers and his internet stations are always busy. In the future he wants to expand and buy more computers as he doesn't have enough for all the young people who need this service. This will be Dan's ninth loan with MFP. He also enjoys working with his community bank. He will use the loan to repair his computers as they need to be in good condition for daily use.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Computer maintenance

loans.name: Stinga

texts.en: Mr. I. Stinga deals in several types of activities, namely, raising of pigs, cultivatI. of cereals and repair of motor home, for which he has all the necessary equipment. I. owns 5.6 hectares of land in Zîrneşti, Cahul district. Near his house, there are two greenhouses built with a total area of approximately 6 hectares where he grows tomatoes and cucumbers. I. sells pork and vegetables at the wholesale market in the district. Business is profitable because of permanently increasing demand for agricultural products, and there are chances of further business development. The purpose of the loan is to purchase food for pigs and film for greenhouse.

loans.use: to purchase food for pigs and film for greenhouse

loans.name: Barrio Maria Auxiliadora Group

texts.es:
El presente Comité denominado Barrio Maria Auxiliadora integran 19 mujeres, todas ellas mayores de edad, residentes en de la compañía Cabañas de la ciudad de Caacupé.

En la actualidad el comité opera en su 10mo. ciclo recibiendo  un promedio de guaranies 578.000 por cada integrante y las mismas la invirtieron en la compra de productos tales como arroz, leche, carne, fideo, gaseosas, semillas para plantas, ropas nuevas y usadas, algunas de las integrantes venden estos productos en forma ambulante lo cual implica un esfuerzo mucho mayor para comercializar estos productos.

Una de las caracteristica de este comité es de que son muy unidas y cada fín de semana realizan actividades para aumentar y capitalizar el ahorro interno del grupo.

Todas las integrantes agracedecen a la Fundación Paraguaya por el apoyo que están recibiendo no solo por los préstamos que recibierón sino también por las capacitaciones permanente que recibe especialmente cuando van renovar el préstamo y también por brindarle la oportunidades  de que promuevan la creación de pequeños negocios y por ende generar recursos económicos y empleos para familiares.

1.	Maria C.             Venta de pollo               
2.	Victoria B.                Kiosko                            
3.	Guillermina E.        Despensa                       
4.	Rosa B.                Venta de ropas               
5.	Maria B.               Despensa                       
6.	Mirian F.                Despensa                       
7.	Herminia B.          Venta de chipa               
8.	Rosa L.            Venta de chipa               
9.	Ana B.                 Despensa                       
10.	Sebastiana V.         Venta de ropa                 
11.	Herminia O.          Venta de chipa                
12.	Maria B.              Despensa                       
13.	Mirta G.             Despensa                        
14.	Eliodora O.           Venta de plantas             
15.	Ruth C.            Despensa                       
16.	Maria D.                   Venta de gaseosa           
17.	Silvia B.               Despensa                   
18.	Carmen Colmán          Despensa                        
19.	Rosa E.          Venta de plantas
texts.en:
The group Barrio Maria Auxiliadora is made up of 19 adult women. They live in La Compañía Cabañas in the city of Caacupé. The group is in their tenth cycle of receiving an average of 578,000 PYG ($113) per member. They bought products such as rice, milk, meat, noodles, soft drinks, seeds for planting, and new and used clothes. It requires a lot more effort to market these products in the streets as some of the members do. This group is very united. Every week end they carry out activities to increase and capitalize upon the group’s savings. All of the group members are grateful to the Fundación Paraguaya for the support they are receiving. They are grateful not only for the loans they have received, but also for the good advice. They appreciate the opportunities offered to create small businesses that generate economic resources and employment for family members. 1. Maria C. Sells Chicken 2. Victoria B. Kiosk 3. Guillermina E. Grocery Store 4. Rosa B. Sells Clothes 5. Maria B. Grocery Store 6. Mirian F. Grocery Store 7. Herminia B. Sells “Chipa” (A typical bread in Paraguay) 8. Rosa L. Sells “Chipa” (A typical bread in Paraguay) 9. Ana B. Grocery Store 10. Sebastiana V. Sells Clothes 11. Herminia O. Sells “Chipa” (A typical bread in Paraguay) 12. Maria B. Grocery Store 13. Mirta G. Grocery Store 14. Eliodora O. Sells Plants 15. Ruth C. Grocery Store 16. Maria D. Sells Soft Drinks 17. Silvia B. Grocery Store 18. Carmen Colmán Grocery Store 19. Rosa E. Sells Plants

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise such as:  fruit, vegetables meat,cosmetics,raw materials for chipa (bread),coal,soft drinks,noodles,rice, milk eggs, and others

loans.name: Ceferina

texts.es:
La señora Ceferina es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres Trabajando por el Desarrollo”, del distrito Cabanilla, Provincia D. Lampa, en el departamento D. Puno; ella tiene 54 años D. edad, ella es casada, es madre D. 04 hijos, ella posee estudios D. segundo D. primaria. 

Ella es socia nueva  con el Movimiento Manuela R., se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes en su tienda, ella desea solicitar un préstamo D. S/ 500.00 nuevos soles, para comprar productos  primera necesidad como arroz, harina, mantequilla, etc. y asimismo se compromete a pagar sus cuotas en 6 meses.

Su deseo es colocar una tienda más granD.  y tener un negocio donD. puedan obtener buenas ganancias. Ella se siente  contenta por pertenecer a Movimiento Manuela R. y le gusta los ahorros que posee.
texts.en:
Ceferina M. E. D. R. is a member of the Communal Bank "Women Working for Development," of the Cabanilla district, in the Lampa province, department of Puno. She is 54 years old, married, and the mother of 4 children. She completed second graD.. She is a new member of the Manuela R. Movement. She sells groceries at her store. She is asking for a loan of 500 soles ($175) to buy staples such as rice, flour, butter, etc., and she commits to repaying the loan within 6 months. Her goal is to establish a larger store and have a business that makes a good profit. She is very proud to be a member of the Manuela R. Movement.

Translated from Spanish by Lisette Artiga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy staples to resell at her store.

loans.name: Naziran Malik Niamat Ali Group

texts.en:
Naziran baji has resided in a mid-size city named Riwind in Pakistan for the last 14 years. Her husband's name is M. N. A. who operates a cooking oil selling business. He has 5 years of experience in this business. Naziran baji is applying for a loan to buy more cooking oil to expand her husband’s cooking oil selling business.

She is the leader of a group with one another lady and her name is Bashiran. Bashiran baji is applying for a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Analie

texts.en: "My husband and I are tilling a 3-hectare (7.5-acre) farm. We never mind the labor or working under the heat of the sun, plowing the wet field just to ensure an abundant harvest from our farm," says Analie M., 30-year-old mother of five children. She would like to ask for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizers, herbicides and other farm necessities. The loan will really help a lot, especially in improving the soil condition of her farm and protecting the crops from damaging insects. By doing so, Mrs. M. believes that she will be able to improve their yield. CEVI helps small businesses to grow. It provides its clients with not just loans - it includes training and insurance coverage as part of its services.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, herbicides and other farm necessities

loans.name: Salimiti

texts.en:
Salimiti is 49 year old, from Mwanza. She is married with six children all between the ages of 13 and 18

Salimiti has run a poultry business since 2003. Raising Kuku (chicken in Swahili) is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. They require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two, and add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally! They require little space, so you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. While they grow they produce eggs, which can be sold to supplement her income or eaten to provide a source of protein.

She works at the business 12 hours a day, seven days per week and is assisted by one employee. Salimiti earns about $140 from her business. She requests a loan of $400 to purchase more chickens. In the future, she plans to expand her business. Salimiti thanks you for your support!

-------------------------------- ABOUT SELFINA SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: Purchase chickens.

loans.name: Paula Elizabeth

texts.es: Paula Elizabeth R. D. D. D. 41 años D. edad resiD. en Lourdes Colón junto a sus cuatro hijos todos menores D. edad los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Ella posee un salón D. belleza en la cual trabaja diariamente para darles todo lo necesario a sus hijos. Paula solicita un préstamo para mejorar las condiciones D. su negocio, así también poder comprar nuevo producto como Shampoo, cremas y otros productos para el cuidado personal, ella desea crecer más en su negocio y así obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Paula Elizabeth R. D. D. is 41 years old and lives in Lourdes Colón with her four children who are all minors and in school. She has a beauty salon in which she works every day so that she can give her children everything they need. Paula is requesting a loan to improve the conditions in her store and also to be able to buy new products like shampoo, conditioner and other personal hygiene products. She hopes to grow her business more and thus generate more income.

Translated from Spanish by Alex Jaffe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase new products for her beauty salon

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Benkadi 5 De Toura Nabitokan Group

texts.fr:
BENKADI 5  est un groupe de  femmes mariées du village de Toura Nabitokan de la ville de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 47 ans, au moins 4 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe BENKADI 5 de TOURA  NABITOKAN ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  le  prêt précédent, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, exclusivement  au grand marché de Kimparana  ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe BENKADI 5 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 30 000 à 25 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The BENKADI 5 group is made of married women of the Toura Nabitokan village, in the city of SAN (Ségou Region, fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali), who live in traditional families. They average 47 years of age, and have at least 4 children. They grow peanuts.

Eager to make their agricultural businesses profitable, the members of the BENKADI 5 group decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, two years ago. After having repaid the previous loan without problems, they are now seeking their second farming loan.

This loan will be used to buy, exclusively at the grand market in Kimparana, a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields. After the rainy season, the crops are stored for a while to gain market value, before being sold at the grand market in Kimparara and in the surrounding markets, retail (often wholesale) and for cash, to a clientele usually coming from the larger cities.

After selling their products, the members of the BENKADI 5 group count on turning a profit of XOF 30000 to 25000 (ca US$ 65 to 55) each, to be used to repay the loan and to pay for the daily expenses of their families.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanut seeds, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields

loans.name: Nakalama C 1 East Basalaki Mwayikuma Group

texts.en: Basalaki M. is 31 years old. She is blessed with seven children going to school and she is taking care of two dependents within her family. She has a video library where she sells movies and recorded music and rents movies, so far for one year. She is using the loan to purchase items such as movies and so forth for her customers. According to her, her business is beneficial to her community in that is she is bringing a service to her customers, because people from her area could collect movies from Iganga town, but now the library is closer. She is a creative married businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase movies for her video library

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita L. is from the village of Pines. She is 66 years old. Lolita is widowed and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Lolita owns and operates a "sari-sari" (variety) store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Lolita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita has successfully repaid previous loans from PMPC. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 16th loan taken out by Lolita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marlene

texts.es: La señora Marlene vive en anticretico junto a sus padres y su hija,  en la calle Tomas Rodríguez Nº 46 de la ciudad de La Paz; la señora vende masitas en los colegios todos los días a pedido, trabaja junto a su madre la cual le ayuda en la venta de las mismas; el objetivo del crédito es para comprar más harina, azúcar y otros ingredientes  para aumentar su  producción y  la venta de las masitas para obtener mejores ingresos.
texts.en:
Sra. Marlene lives in a rental property with her parents and her daughter on #46 Tomas Rodríguez Street in the city of La Paz. She sells cookies on demand every day at the high schools. She works with her mother, who helps with making sales.

This loan will be used to buy more flour, sugar, and other ingredients to increase her cookie production and sales, which will improve her income.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase flour, sugar, and other ingredients for making cookies

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian B. lives in the village of Sitio Coop, Brgy. Anahaw, Hinigaran Negros Occidental. She is 35 years old and married to Eulogio B., who is presently employed as Kabo (supervisor) in a sugarcane plantation. They have an adopted child, Jasmine, who is eight years old. The couple is still hoping to have their own baby someday. Even though she has a small family, Vivian still prepares for their future. She still helps her husband raise their weekly income. 

The family has their own small rice farm that supports the food needs of the family. This gave Vivian the idea to make the rice field more productive. In the year 2002 she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to have capital for her farm to buy seeds and fertilizer and to pay for labor. Since the rice is harvested after three months, Vivian worked in the sugarcane plantation in the meantime. After harvesting the rice, she had it milled and sold it to the people in her community and also to the sugarcane workers. The rice business earns an average of PHP 4,000 per month, which is enough for her small family, with savings left for their future security.

Her previous loan of Php 17,000 was used as working capital for her farm. She paid all of her weekly installments on time and the loan was fully paid within the loan term, maintaining her status as a good member of NWTF_Project Dungganon. Now she is borrowing Php 19,000 to add to her capital for her rice farm to have a better living standard in the future.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To increase her capital

loans.name: Rayo De Luz 1, 2 And 3 Group

texts.en:
Maria is the group coordinator for Banco D. Esperanza (Bank of Hope) Rayo D. Luz (Ray of Light). Her story is representative of the others in her group and also more generally of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients. Maria lives in Hato Mayor, a rural area in the Dominican Republic.  Her house has unreliable access to non-potable running water and electricity. She lives in a house with her husband and 10-year-old son. 

Maria operates a bakery that sells sweets called Dulces D. Maria. She runs her business out of her home and sells sweets, bread and other food items like fruit juice.  This will be her fourth loan with Esperanza after successfully paying back her previous three loans.  She plans to use this loan to purchase food items to sell and ingredients so she can make items to sell.  She specifically needs flour, rice, sugar, oil, eggs and butter.  

Maria wants to continue to improve her living conditions by working hard and advancing her family.  Her dream is to one day be able to afford her own pastry store so she doesn't have to operate her business from her home.

loans.use: Food products including: butter, sugar, oil, eggs, flour, rice, wheat

loans.name: Cyriane

texts.fr: La cliente est née le 18 Mars 1975 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Elle est mariée et est mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés. La cliente vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Elle a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au cours primaire, et depuis neuf ans, elle exerce la couture et vend également des articles de mercerie au marché de Midombo. Elle achète ses articles à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Pour rehausser le niveau de son activité et faire face à la demande de sa clientèle, elle sollicite auprès de ALIDé un premier crédit.
texts.en:
The client was born on March 18, 1975 in Porto-Novo, administrative capital of Bénin. She is married and is the mother of two children, both enrolled in school. She helps her husband out in supporting the family. She went through primary school, but since the age of 9, she has been working at sewing, and she also sells sewing notions in the market of Midombo. She buys her goods in Dantokpa, international market of Bénin. In order to expand her business and meet the needs of her clientele, she is asking ALIDé for a first ever loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of sewing supplies for resale

loans.name: Nora

texts.en: Nora is twenty-eight years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all in school. She lives with her family in a rented apartment in Kade. Kade is a farming/commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Nora is a trader. She runs a grocery store by the roadside in her community. She sells various kinds of groceries, from toiletries to candies. She has been in business for barely a year now and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to increase her stock. Nora desires to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To purchase assorted groceries

loans.name: Virgelia

texts.en:
Virgelia D. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan De Oro City. She is 51 years old. Virgelia is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Virgelia owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Virgelia has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Virgelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virgelia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Virgelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Marcela

texts.es:
Marcela Nolorbe es una socia dinámica y optimista, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa, región de Ucayali. Ella tiene 55 años, es viuda y madre de ocho hijos mayores de edad los cuales la apoyan.
Se dedica a la venta de verduras en el mercado de Bellavista-Pucallpa.  
Es nueva socia y forma parte del Banco Comunal “Madres Corajes”. El primer préstamo que recibirá es de 300.00 nuevos soles los que utilizará en la compra de frutas y verduras regionales. 
La meta de Marcela es llegar a tener una tienda de golosinas y seguir apoyando a su familia en los gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
Marcela Nolorbe, 55, is a dynamic, optimistic woman from the city of Pucallpa, Ucayali region. She is a widow and has 8 adult children who help support her. She is a vegetable merchant in Pucallpa's Bellavista market. She is a new member of the "Madres Corajes" communal bank. The first loan she will receive will be for 300 new soles that she'll use to buy regional fruits and vegetables. Marcela's goal is to have a sweet shop and to continue supporting her family with household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy regional fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Monica Alexandra

texts.es:
El banco comunal Fuerza del Mañana está formado por mujeres emprendedoras, visionarias micro empresarias cabeza de hogar que residen en  distintas localidades de la urbe cuencana,  ésta ciudad majestuosa y soberana se caracteriza por  la riqueza de su arquitectura y valor histórico  así como su  paisaje de inigualable belleza por lo que   ha sido declarada Patrimonio Cultural de la Humanidad.

Es así que Mónica B. tiene 29 años y es una de las  socias activas  hace cuatro ciclos,  vive en el centro de la ciudad  con su esposo, él trabaja como mecánico industrial y ella como consultora de belleza,  aun no tienen hijos y tampoco casa propia.

 Mónica se dedica a la venta de productos Yanbal por catálogo, lleva un año realizando esta actividad  que le ha dado muchas satisfacciones, sus clientes son principalmente su familia sus amigas y ex compañeros de trabajo.

Nuestra socia nos comenta que una tía la incentivó para que forme parte del banco comunal, los créditos recibidos ha invertido en adquirir mercadería para su negocio  y con el nuevo préstamo que recibirá de la Fundación va a comprar perfumes, cremas, labiales, rímel, pinta uñas y mas cosméticos para damas y caballeros.

Su mayor sueño es tener su casa propia.
texts.en:
“Fuerza del Mañana” (“Strength for Tomorrow”) Communal Bank is made of enterprising woman. They are visionary entrepreneurs who are the heads of their households and reside in various locations around the city of Cuenca. Cuenca is a majestic city known for its architectural richness and historical importance and has been declared an important Cultural Heritage Site for its incomparable beauty. Mónica B. is 29, and she has been an active member for four cycles. She lives in the center of the city with her husband. He works as an industrial mechanic, and she is a beauty consultant. They do not have children yet, nor do they have their own house. Mónica sells Yanbal products by catalog. She has been doing this for one year. It has given her a lot of satisfaction. Her customers are primarily her family, friends, and ex colleagues from work. She comments that an aunt motivated her to become part of the communal bank. She has used the loans she has received to acquire merchandise for her business. With the new loan she will receive from the Foundation she will buy perfume, creams, lipsticks, mascara, nail polish, and more cosmetics for women and men. Her greatest dream is to have her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy perfume, cream, lipstick, shadow, mascara, nail polish, and more cosmetics for women and men

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more sorghum and maize for her business

loans.name: Vann

texts.en:
Mrs. Vann U. was born in 1969 and she was married many years ago to Mr. Bieng Hen, age 43. They are local rice cultivators. This couple has five children, four of whom are attending school, and the other one helps feed the family by driving a taxi. 

Vann U. has been planning to invest in a new enterprise line in order to improve her family's income, but she doesn’t have enough money to start the process. Therefore, she has requested a loan to buy many sets of spare parts for general, everyday machinery to sell. She is hopeful that this will provide her with additional income. 

Note: Vann U. was not available, so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy many sets of spare parts of general machines.

loans.name: Marta

texts.es:
Martha, de 30 años, vive en su casa propia en compañía de su esposo Luciano (31) y de sus 2  hijos; Luzbeth (11) y Dayma (5).
Desde muy pequeña sus padres le enseñaron las técnicas de la agricultura, es por eso que cuando se casó y formó su propia familia no dudó en ayudar a su esposo con el sustento del hogar, sembrando maíz en grandes cantidades. Le gusta mucho la labor de campo, ya que sabe muy bien cómo se realiza y le da buenas ganancias, pues el maíz que cosecha lo vende a un molino de la zona y tiene el dinero asegurado. Lo que no le agrada es que tiene que estar en constante vigilancia de sus cultivos, pues son asediados por los pájaros que destruyen gran cantidad de su producción. Pero aun así le agrada mucho sembrar para después ver el fruto de su esfuerzo en los dorados granos. Y como es una mujer muy laboriosa, que siempre se proyecta al futuro, tiene planeado sembrar otro tipo de vegetales en sus tierras para incrementar su producción.

Esta es la 1ra vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP y promete será puntual en el pago de sus cuotas, ya que no quiere atrasarse y dejar mal al grupo de trabajo que le ha depositado su confianza. El dinero que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de semilla de alverja y papa, así como fertilizantes y abono para el cuidado de sus tierras.
texts.en:
Marta is 30 years old and lives in her own home with her husband Luciano (age 31) and their two children, Luzbeth (age 11) and Dayma (age 5).

As a young girl, Marta’s parents taught her the techniques used in farming. When she got married and started her own family, she did not hesitate in helping her husband with supporting their household. She utilized her skills by planting corn in large quantities. Marta enjoys working in the fields and knows what is needed to succeed and generate good profits. She sells her crop of corn to the local mill and earns the money to provide security for her family. The part of the job she dislikes is the need to constantly monitor the crops because birds have been known to destroy a large part of her harvest. Even with this inconvenience, she enjoys seeing the golden kernels that are the fruits of her labor. Marta is a very industrious woman who always looks to the future. She plans to grow other types of vegetables on her land in order to increase her production.

This is her first loan from MFP. Marta promises to be punctual in making her payments because she does not want to create tension and ill feelings among the other group members who have placed their trust in her. She will use the money to purchase seeds for growing peas and potatoes, as well as fertilizer and compost for maintaining her land.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seeds & fertilizers

loans.name: Rac

texts.en: Rac N. is married and has 2 children. He was born in 1962. This man is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town, now settled in the Absheron region. He has been in this business for 7 years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy 4 calves to expand his business and attract more clients.

loans.use: To buy 4 calves

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn L. is a 48-year-old woman living in the town of Prk. Kabatohan, Brgy. Tabunan, Bago City Negros Occidental . She is married and has 4 adult-aged children. Marilyn owns and operates a small sari sari store, otherwise known as a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Marilyn has been involved in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2006, Marilyn joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from NWTF. Marilyn is now requesting a new loan, her 5th, for 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. Marilyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anunsacion

texts.en:
Anunsacion A. is from the village of Balbagon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 49 years old. Anunsacion is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a tailoring business, providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $90 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Anunsacion joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Anunsacion is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and sewing materials. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family and to support the education of her child. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Ahmadkhon

texts.en: A. Ahmadkhon is 32 years old. He has had a trying life but he keeps an optimistic outlook on it. He remains a strong and persevering person, intent on improving his family’s standard of living. Ahmadkhon sells fuel like petrol (gasoline) and diesel fuel. With over two years of selling fuel, he already has got enough experience to do his work successfully and has clients who always come to him. Today Ahmadkhon is requesting a loan of 3000 USD that will be used to increase his stock of fuel to meet his clients' demand. The well-being of this family is in your hands. Help them by contributing to the growth of Ahmadkhon’s business and they will sincerely thank you. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase more fuel to sell to expand his business

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Mrs. Neang H. (pictured above), age 56 and her husband, Mr. Soeun Kong, age 63, have been married for eight years and have one daughter. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Neang has been operating a grocery store since 1980. She buys grocery items from Phnom Penh market for resale and operates her store in front of her house. Her husband assists his wife in the business.  

Neang is asking for a loan of $500 to purchase grocery items for resale in her business.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Pen T., 38, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its clay and ceramic products.

T. is a housewife while her husband is a police officer, earning an income of USD 7 per day to help cover the family expenses.

T. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to buy wood to build a store near the market to start a new business selling groceries. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

In the future, T. would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy wood to build a store near the market

loans.name: Virgen Del Carmen Group

texts.es:
Las socias del Banco Comunal Virgen del Carmen son del Distrito D. Pacaycasa que se encuentra a 30 minutos D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho.
Petronila es la presidenta del Banco Comunal y lo que mas le gusta del Banco Comunal son las capacitaciones en temas D. familia.
Petronila es casada y tiene 2 hijos que estudian, Petronila junto a su esposo se dedican a la fabricación D. ladrillos artesanales que venD. crudos para luego ser quemados. También se dedica a la compra D. tara y cochinilla en las diferentes comunidades D. su distrito, para lo cual cuenta con la ayuda D. su hijo y tiene un carro con el cual acopian estos productos, sus ventas los realiza a un mayorista. Además Petronila venD. comida los días sábados y domingos en el estadio D. su comunidad, prepara varios platos típicos D. la zona. Su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. ají, papa, arroz por sacos. Petronila desea comprar un terreno para la construcción D. una casa para sus hijos y tener mas capital.
texts.en:
The members of the Virgen del Carmen Communal Bank are from the Pacaycasa district, which is 30 minutes from the city of Ayacucho. Petronila is the president of the communal bank. What she likes the most about the communal bank are the trainings about families. Petronila is married and has two children who go to school. Petronila and her husband make handmaD., unbaked bricks. They sell them to be baked later. She also buys “tara” (a Peruvian plant whose tannins are most commonly used in the manufacture of furniture leather) and “cochinilla” (an insect used to make a red dye) in the different communities in her district. Her son helps her. She has a car where she keeps the products that she sells wholesale. Petronila also sells food on Saturdays and Sundays in the stadium in her community. She makes various dishes that are typical in her area. The loan is to buy chili peppers, potatoes, and sacks of rice. Petronila wishes to buy land in order to build a house for her children and to have more capital.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy chili peppers, potatoes, and sacks of rice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: He is going to use the money for construction materials for his home, he is going to build a wall.

loans.name: Sabougnouman  4 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Sabougnouman  4 sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 46 ans et en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Fatiana, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres l’arachide,   le petit mil et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le premier a été bien remboursé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, DJOMINE D. compte acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 hectare d’arachide et de haricot.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Fana après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 25.000FCFA par campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Sabougnouman 4 group are married women who average 46 years of age with an average of two children each. The majority of them live in polygamous families in Fatiana, one of the villages of the prefecture of Dioïla, in the Koulikoro region, which is the second administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the aim of better organising their activities at the beginning of the winter season. The crops they cultivate include peanuts, pearl millet and beans. They are on their second farming loan, and the first was paid on time. With this new loan, Djomine D. is planning to buy intrants, before the price increases, and small equipment, as well as paying the labor costs of maintaining around a hectare of peanuts and beans. The produce, once harvested, is sold in the towns of Dioïla and Fana, to a customer base made up of men and women. The women are expecting to make an average profit of 25,000FCFA at the end of the season.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of intrants and small equipment, plus labor costs

loans.name: David

texts.en:
Most people from western Uganda have embarked on profitable business ventures using savings from their farming and milk-selling businesses. Three years ago, 54-year-old David T. went with this tide and started his retail shop in Burambara-Rukungiri. This business has been, in many ways, his recourse in dealing with the many demands that come with providing for a family and meeting the costs of operating a business. 

David, a happy-go-lucky, married father of five, for the most part sells coffee, beans and ground nuts. In a month, his business generates profits to the sum of 260,000 shillings and with this loan, he wants to buy more retail stock for resale. He specifically wants to buy more beans, ground nuts and rice.

loans.use: Buying more beans, ground nuts and rice for resale

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen B. is from the village of Brgy. Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 57 years old. Helen is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Helen operates a tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Helen has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2008, Helen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. Helen is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional tailoring equipment, such as needles and threads. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Helen from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional tailoring equipment, such as needles and threads

loans.name: Johanna

texts.en:
Johanna O. is from the town of Bunawan. She is 35 years old. Johanna is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Johanna raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. She does her best to increase her harvest. 

Johanna joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Johanna has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Johanna is requesting a new loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Johanna from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her family.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Lan

texts.en: Lan T. L. is 55 years old with 2 children who are studying at Construction University. She retired some years ago. Her main activities to earn money is running a small shop that serves breakfast and raising pigs. But the income is not much in compared with her large payment of school fee. Joining SEDA credit program in 2006, she is currently requesting a loan of 7,194,000 VND to pay for school fees as the new school year starts.

loans.use: To pay for school fees as the new school year starts.

loans.name: El Hadji

texts.fr: Monsieur El hadji W. habite à Yoff. Il est âgé de 37 ans. Il est marié et père d’un enfant qui est âgé d’un an et demi. Monsieur W. est un fervent musulman qui aide les musulmans à pratiquer leur religion. Par conséquent il a choisi son métier de vendeur de chapelet par passion. La satisfaction qu’elle procure à sa clientèle lui donne une grande fierté. Il exerce cette occupation depuis plus de 10 ans. Aussi  il est en même temps gardien dans une école publique depuis plus de 5 ans. Il est sociétaire de la caisse de Yoff depuis février 2010. Il sollicite un crédit de 100 000 frs qui sera destiné a l’achat de fils et de perles pour pouvoir répondre aux commandes de ses produits. Avec l’amélioration  de ses gains il souhaite mettre sa famille qui vit au village dans de bonnes conditions.
texts.en:
Mr. El Hadji W. lives in Yoff. He is 37 years old. He is married and the father of an 18-month child. 

Mr. W. is a devoted Muslim who helps Muslim practice their religion. Therefore he chose his rosary retail activity with enthusiasm. He gets great pride providing satisfaction to his customers. He has been practicing this activity for 10 years. He has also been a custodian in a public school for over five years.

He has been a member of the Yoff branch since February 2010. He is requesting a loan of 100 000 francs which he will use to buy string and beads in order to fulfill the order of his products.

With the improvement of his revenue, he wishes to improve the living conditions of his family that lives in the village.

loans.use: Strengthening of his working capital.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en: Anecita Danore is from the village of Bagacay, Sibutad. She is 51 years old and married with four adult children. To make a living, Anecita runs a grocery store. Anecita has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2008, Anecita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anecita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. Anecita is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used as additional working capital for the business. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Anecita from PMPC. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for the business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose M. lives in the Wandegeya neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has six children, three of whom are in school.  

Rose has had a restaurant business for three years, and she works six days a week. Her restaurant is in a market, and she sells at retail prices.    

She has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas, cassava beef, chicken and charcoal. The main business challenges for Rose include the rainy season.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked hotel. 

She lives in a home that she rents where she doesn't have access to electricity or piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy morefood staffs for her restaurant like bunches of bananas, rise,cassava, beef, chciken and charcoal

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is a Kiambu-based dairy farmer who has been running his business since 2008. He supplies the milk he produces to milk-processing plants in his region. The market for his product is good and, as a result, he is doing well. He has requested a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase animal feed. Samuel is a single father of two children who are in school. He describes himself as business-oriented and hopes to be successful in what he does. For extra income, Samuel runs a butcher shop in Kiambu.

loans.use: Buying animal feed

loans.name: Kipsoi

texts.en:
B. K. Kipsoi, age 28, buys potatoes in bulk and sells them in small quantities at a profit. He has been in this business for two years now and he gets a monthly income of Kshs 30,000 shillings. He and his wife, Joan K., are blessed with two beautiful children. They live in Kibigos in Tot, Kenya.

B. has applied for a loan from KADET, which he plans to use to add more sacks of potatoes to offer for resale. He will also buy chemicals for spraying potatoes while in the farm to avoid insects from infecting the crop.

In future, he plans to buy a plot and build rental houses. These will supplement his income so that he can provide for his family's basic needs.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of potatoes to offer for resale

loans.name: Maria Del Rosario

texts.es: María del Rosario Martínez S. y su esposo son unas personas muy trabajadoras pensando en ofrecer a sus dos hijos una mejor calidad de vida. La señora con ahorros propios construyo su vivienda en la parte baja e inicio la parte alta; solo que para terminar le falta pagar la mano de obra. Los hijos de Rosario ya están en edad adolescente es por ello que quiere terminar lo antes posible la construcción para que cada uno tenga su propio espacio.
texts.en: María del Rosario Martínez S. and her husband are hardworking people who believe in offering their two children a better quality of life.  With her savings, Sra. María built the lower floor of her home and started the upper part.  In order to finish the job, she needs to pay for labor.  María del Rosario’s children are teenagers, so she wants to finish the construction as soon as possible so that they have their own space.

loans.use: Pay for labor to finish the construction of her house

loans.name: Las Malenitas Group

texts.es: L. foto fue tomada en el negocio D. L. señora María Elena M., una integrante del grupo D. Las Malenitas, que está ubicado en el estado D. VeraC. en México. Se ve a las integrantes y L. tienda D. abarrotes D. L. señora María Elena M. en L. foto. ElL. se dedica a L. venta D. abarrotes que inicio hace 10 años. Solicita el préstamo para invertir en mercancía y compra D. carnes frías. Sus ganancias aumentaron gracias al crédito que le otorgamos. Al momento D. solicitar este préstamo se siente muy contenta. Tiene 45 años estudió hasta L. secundaria, es madre y tiene en total 3 hijos; 2 mujeres y 1 hombre. Quiere este crédito para surtir en L. venta D. abarrotes y compra D. carnes frías. También espera seguir contando con el apoyo D. KIVA y CrediComún, para ir mejorando sus ganancias. El grupo está conformado por 12 integrantes.
texts.en:
The photo was taken in Mrs. María Elena M.’s business.  She’s a member of the Las Malenitas group which is located in the state of VeraC. in México.  One can see the members and Mrs. María Elena M.’s grocery store in the photo.  She has sold groceries for the last 10 years.  She is asking for the loan to invest in merchandise and to buy cold cuts. Her profits increased thanks to the loan we granted her.

At the moment of requesting this loan she feels very happy.  She is 45 years old and went up to secondary school.  She’s a mother of three children: two girls and one boy.

She wants this loan to stock up on groceries and to buy cold cuts.

She expects to continue to have KIVA and CrediComún support to continue improving her profits.  The group has 12 members.

loans.use: To buy merchandise and invest in cold cuts.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya sont des femmes mariées, elles ont en moyenne 38 ans, 4 enfants et vivent avec leurs maris et enfants dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Coulibalyla, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et font la restauration, le commerce de bétail, de savons et d’articles divers.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Danaya sont à leur premier prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso.                                                                          
DOUSSOU C. s’approvisionne en bétail auprès des éleveurs du village et environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes au niveau du village et au marché de Dioïla pendant les jours de foires au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 50 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer le prêt, et effectuer les dépenses personnelles.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group are married women. On average, they are 38 years old, have 4 children and live with their husbands and children in extended traditional families in the village of Coulibalyla, prefecture of Dioïla, region of Koulikoro (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They know each other through family and neighborhood ties. They are engaged in the restaurant business and in the sale of livestock, soaps and various other items.                                                                                     

The women of the Danaya group are on their first solidarity loan with Soro Yiriwaso. 
                                                                         
DOUSSOU C. gets her supplies of livestock from cattle farmers in the village and its outskirts. She makes her sales in the village and at the market in Dioïla on fair days, for cash or credit, to a customer-base composed of women and men.

She expects to make an average monthly profit of 50,000 CFA francs that will be used to repay the loan and cover personal expenses.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es: El señor Francisco tiene 34 años, tiene 3 hijos menores de edad a su cargo. Su negocio es muy peculiar como es la elaboración de ataúdes y brindar el servicio de funeraria. El señor inicio este negocio hace 10 años, ya que lo aprendió en el salvador luego decidió establecerse en su vivienda, para generar ingresos para su hogar.  El señor está solicitando este crédito para realizar la compra de herramientas, madera, pega, clavos, entre otras cosas. Su mayor sueño siempre ha sido tener mejores equipos y más actualizados lógicamente brinden mayores ganancias.
texts.en: Francisco is 34 years old and has 3 young children in his care. His business is rather peculiar as he makes coffins and is a funerary services supplier. He started his business 10 years ago. He learned his craft in El Salvador and later decided to set up his workshop in his own home, so as to generate income for his family. He is requesting this loan to purchase tools, wood, glue and nails, among other things. His biggest dream has always been to have better and more up-to-date equipment so as to obtain higher returns.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Cheng's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of thirteen members. They are located in Preaek Svay village in Kandal province.

Mrs. Cheng S. was born in 1980 and is a married woman. She is the village bank president. She was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. She stays at home and takes care of her two children. Her husband, Mr. Mok Simon, is a teacher at a private schoO. where he can earn a little salary to support his family.

Now the house where they live has flooded, so Mrs. Cheng S. would like to ask for a loan to buy soil to fill in her land. 

This couple has two children: one is attending a local schoO. and the younger one is only 4 years old.

loans.use: To buy soil for filling in her land

loans.name: Beatriz Eugenia

texts.es:
Para salir adelante con sus hijas y superar la separación de su esposo, Beatriz Eugenia M. D. encontró en su negocio una oportunidad para convertirse en madre cabeza de hogar y superar las dificultades. 

Desde hace 3 años esta emprendedora con sus pocos ahorros y algunos préstamos le dio vida a su negocio de venta de ropa donde además presta servicios de bordado. Es así como Beatriz lucha día a día para sacar a sus dos hijas adelante. 

Actualmente Beatriz necesita de un crédito para comprar mercancía y abastecerse de algunas prendas que le hacen falta para ofrecer mayor variedad a sus clientes.
texts.en:
In order to support her daughters and to survive the separation from her husband, Beatriz Eugenia M. D. found an opportunity in her business that would let her become the head of the household and to overcome their difficulties. 

Three years ago this enterprising woman started her clothing and embroidery business with the few savings she had and some personal loans. This is how Beatriz works day after day to support her two daughters. 

Beatriz requests a loan to purchase merchandise and to supply her with some articles of clothing that she needs to increase the variety of goods to offer her clients.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for resale.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah A. is from the village of Libertad, Gingoog City, in the province of Misamis Oriental. She is 30 years old, is married, and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Leah owns and operates a tailoring business in the services sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing general alteration and tailoring services to community members for clothing such as dresses and school uniforms. Leah has been engaged in her business for more than 4 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. The picture above was taken outside her house where a garden of flowers is located.

Leah joined HSPFI in 2010 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase tailoring equipment such as needles and thread. Leah is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fabrics and other materials. This will be her second loan from HSPFI. Leah plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and/or expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc. (HSPFI) is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and other materials

loans.name: Chen

texts.en: Chen R., 37, lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. He makes a living by recycling various items, and earns about $4 a day. Each month, his family spends about $70 on food and $20 on other necessities. R. is requesting a loan of $250 to buy a motorbike, which he will use to transport the recyclable materials he resells. This will be his first loan fR. CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to carry recyclable materials

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is married with 3 children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Jane is 49 years old and has one child who is in school.

Jane has a food vending business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF to buy spices, meat, and other ingredients for her food vending.

Jane has been in this business for 10 years.  In the future, Jane would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food vending

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en: Angelina is currently in a business of selling green vegetables. She is 40 years old, married, with 4 children and 2 of them go to school. Angelina borrowed a loan to stock more green vegetables to sell. She hopes to expand her business with extra profits in the future.

loans.use: Stock more green vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Cruz María

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Mujeres De Lucha se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo. Lugar conocido por ser una zona muy comercial, por sus fiestas tradicionales de San Pedro y San Pablo y por la alegría de su gente.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Cruz, tiene 69 años de edad, hace varios años su esposo falleció pero de esta relación tuvo diez hijos todos mayores de edad e independientes, con ella vive una hija con sus tres nietos que son su razón de vivir.

Ella tiene un pequeño local  en las calles Chile y Alajuela en la ciudad de Portoviejo en el cual se dedica a la venta de aliños y especias, pastas de dientes, papel higiénico, entre otras muchas cosas, aquí en este sector todos los días hay una gran afluencia de personas que llegan a realizar sus compras diarias, trabaja todos los días desde las 06h00 hasta las 18h00, nos cuenta que lleva en esta actividad 15 años y que de esta forma ella pudo sacar adelante a sus hijos después de la muerte de su querido esposo.

Este crédito es para comprar aliños, detergentes, pastas dentales, entre otras cosas. Está en el Banco Comunal desde el inicio y le gusta porque con estos créditos le han sacado de muchos apuros económicos.

Su sueño es tener una tienda de abarrotes para ya no tener que salir a vender fuera de su casa.
texts.en:
The Mujeres De Lucha [Tenacious Women] Communal Bank meets every two weeks in Picoaza parish in the city of Portoviejo, known for being a very commercial area, for its traditional fiestas for San Pedro and San Pablo, and for the happiness of its people. 

Cruz is 69 years old. Her husband died several years ago, but she still has their 10 children, all of whom are grown and independent. One daughter and her family live with Cruz, and her three grandchildren are her reason for living. She has a small shop at Chile and Alajuela Streets in Portoviejo where she sells seasonings and spices, toothpaste, toilet paper, and many other things. Every day a great number of people come to the area to do their daily shopping. She works every day from 6:00am until 6:00pm. She says she has run her shop for 15 years and this was how she gave her children a good start after the death of her beloved husband. 

This loan is to purchase seasonings, detergents, toothpaste, and other items. She has been in the communal bank since it began and she likes it because these loans have gotten her out of many tight spots economically. Her dream is to have a grocery store in her house so that she can work from home.

loans.use: to purchase seasonings, detergents, tooth paste, etc. for her shop.

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: Akosua is a peddler in slippers, shoes and sandles at Kwaprow, near Abura, in Cape Coast. Akosua has been through junior high school. She is married to a driver and together they take care of their four children. Akosua has been in this business for 5 years. She helps in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more slippers and shoes for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to build a shop.

loans.use: to buy more slippers and shoes for resale

loans.name: Lucy Ines

texts.es:
La señora Lucy es socia del banco comunal El Arenal del Distrito Calleria, Departamento de Ucayali, tiene 57 años de edad, está casada y tiene tres hijos.
Los 15 años que viene trabajando con los préstamos de Manuela Ramos le ha servido para poder contar con el capitalnecesario para atender algunos pedidos de costura, la señora Lucy confecciona blusas, sabanas, manteles, toallas... todo lo que sea costura, es un oficio que le encanta y lo hace con mucho gusto.
Con su nuevo préstamo de S/. 2,000.00 nuevos soles comprarà: 10 metros de tela, hilos para bordado, agujas punta roma, 5 metros de tela cañamazo para el bordado en punto cruz.
Le encanta su trabajo, de esa manera también se distrae, por las tardes tiene la compañía de su nieto con el cual pasa buenos momentos.
Seguirá trabajando con Manuela Ramos porque es como su otra familia, amistades encontradas que están durando muchos años juntas
texts.en:
Lucy is a member of the "El Arenal" community bank which is located in Calleria district, in Ucayali department.  She is 57 years old, married, and has three children.

Lucy has been working with Manuela Ramos loans for 15 years and they have provided her with the capital she has needed to fill some of her sewing orders.  Lucy makes blouses, sheets, tablecloths and towels... everything sewing related.  It is a job that she loves and she does it very happily.

Lucy will use this new loan for 2,000 Peruvian soles to buy 10 meters of fabric, embroidery threads, needles and 5 meters of embroidery canvas for doing cross stitch work.

Lucy loves her work and she enjoys doing it.  In the afternoons, she has the company of her grandson and they spend some good moments together.

Lucy will continue working with Manuela Ramos because it is like her other family.  She has made friendships which have lasted many years.

loans.use: to buy fabric and thread

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel is 32 years old and married. She has 3 school-aged children. She has a clothing business where she sells different kinds of clothes in the local community.

Maribel is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy additional clothes to sell. Each month, Maribel earns about PHP 5,000 doing this type of work. In the future, Maribel hopes that her business will improve to support the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional clothes to sell.

loans.name: Jose Gabriel

texts.es: José Gabriel tiene 59 años, el ha sabido ganarse la vida por lo que su actividad económica es brindar el servicio de soldador. Hace más de 22 años que se dedica a este negocio, ya que cuando el inicio fue desde muy joven que empezó en un taller y decide establecer su propio negocio. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de estaño, soldador eléctrico, soplete con cartuchos y otros. Su deseo es tener su propio lugar de trabajo.
texts.en: José Gabriel is 59 years old.  He has learned to make a living by offering his services as a welder.  He has been making his living in this business for more than 22 years.  When he first started, he was very young and worked in a workshop.  He has decided to set up his own business.  The loan that he is requesting is for the purchase of solder, an electric soldering iron, a gas welding torch with cartridges and other items.  José Gabriel's wish is to have his own work place.

loans.use: to purchase a solder, an electric soldering iron, a gas welding torch with cartridges and other items.

loans.name: Suong

texts.en:
Mrs. Suong has been spending her life cultivating crops in the Kompong Speu Province. This is a skill she learned from her grandparent when she was young. She is now married and has three kids. Her husband works in the garment factory and has a fixed salary each month. Mrs. Suong’s husband faces difficulties with his traveling needs because he always pays a lot of money to a taxi driver when he wants to go to his work place and other places. Therefore, Mrs. Suong hopes to reduce the amount her husband spends on transportation by using her loan to purchase a motorbike. 

Note: Mrs. Suong and her husband are shown in the photo.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.name: Khawla

texts.en:
Khawla is 45 years old. Her husband Waleed has recently retired. They have three sons and two daughters. Khawla is a hard working mother who makes different kinds of spices such as thyme and sumac and sells them at the market. Her plan in the future is to have her own land to grow plants so she can make more types of spices. To do that she has applied for a loan to buy more ingredients to make the spices as a start until she has enough money to buy a small piece of land.

Since Khawla is a conservative person, she asked that her husband Waleed appear in the picture instead of her.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to make spices

loans.name: Zaverio

texts.en: Zaverio is a 58-year-old, married man with 8 children living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has a dream of educating his children up to higher levels. Zaverio owns a tailoring shop and he specifically deals in school uniforms. He has been in business for 15 years and the major challenge faced now is price fluctuations that result in high operational costs. His dream is to acquire a contract of supplying school uniforms in about 50 schools. Zaverio needs the loan to buy school uniforms for resale.

loans.use: to buy school uniforms for resale

loans.name: Paskali

texts.en: Paskali is a forty two year old married man with eight children. He owns a house in Kasese,Uganda. He has been dealing in clothes for four years.  Initially Paskali sold secondhand clothes but he now sells new clothes. His challenge is high commodity prices and his vision is a big boutique plus educating children. Paskali needs the loan  to buy clothes for resale.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Cindy

texts.es: Cindy de 19 años de edad  y estudiante universitaria,estudiante de Contaduria Pùblica, es una joven que tiene grandes sueños, y diariamente trabaja para lograr alcanzarlos; entusiasta y emprendedora, desde muy niña ha mostrado sus dotes de gran comerciante, primero vendiendo dulces a sus compañera de clases y hoy genera sus propios ingresos, mediante una actividad independiente, porque ella vende productos por catálogos y tiene una miscelánea donde comercializa cosméticos, accesorios, artículos para el hogar, bolsos y calzados fabricados por su propia madre. Ella es muy conocida en su sector en la universidad y en muchos lugares donde llega pues siempre busca las mejores negociaciones para sus clientes, a quienes vende de contado y principalmente a crédito. Su meta es terminar su carrera universitaria y adquirir su propia vivienda y lograr el fortalecimiento y la estabilidad de su negocio. , en la actualidad su negocio genera una rentabilidad del 23,38( y una rotación de sus cuentas por cobrar de 25 días, indicadores financieros desde los cuales proyectamos su potencial crecimiento y auguramos el éxito de la inversión de su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a  la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el cual comprará cosméticos y accesorios en oferta de sus revista, pues su experiencia le indica que debe estar lista para una de las épocas del año en la cual hay mayor repunte en sus ventas y no le quiere fallar a sus rentables clientes.
texts.en:
Cindy, 19, is a university student majoring in public accounting.  She’s a young woman with big dreams and she works daily to make them reality.  She’s enthusiastic and enterprising and has shown her great commercial gifts since she was a little girl first selling candy to her classmates and now earning her own income through an independent activity because she sells catalogue products and she also has a general store where she sells cosmetics, accessories, items for the home, purses and footwear manufactured by her own mother.  She is very well known in her sector in the university and in many other places where she goes because she’s always looking for the best deals for her customers that she sells to for cash and mainly on credit.  Her goal is to finish her university career and get a house of her own and to strengthen her business’ stability.

At present, her business has a 23.38% profit margin and a 25-day accounts receivable turnover.  With these financial indicators we are able to predict potential growth and augur success for the investment of her Kiva loan, the first financing she gets from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo that she’ll use to buy cosmetics and accessories that are on special offer in her catalogues because her experience has taught her that she must be ready for one of the seasons of the year when sales spike and she does not want to disappoint her profitable customers.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics and accessories from her catalogues that are on special promotion

loans.name: Aisalkyn's Group

texts.en:
